ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-1. - Seal. 
    The seal provided and used by the village, with the words "Village of Plainfield, Illinois" around the outer circle and in the center of the seal the word "Seal" shall be the seal of the village. 
(Ord. of 10-25-01; Code 1973, Ch. 1, § 2-1-1) 
State Law reference- Corporate seal of village, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 2-3-8. 
Sec. 2-2. - Freedom of Information Act. 
    The "Village of Plainfield Freedom of Information Act Rules and Regulations" attached to Ordinance No. 2908 as Exhibit "A" are hereby adopted and made a part of this section and shall be utilized by the village to carry out the provisions of the Freedom of Information Act. 
(Ord. No. 1077, § 9-1-1, 1-21-85; Ord. No. 2908, § 3, 12-21-09) 
State Law reference- The Freedom of Information Act, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 116, § 201 et seq. 
Sec. 2-3. - Soil and water conservation district. 
    All territory within the corporate limits of the village, and upon its annexation all territory that shall be annexed to the village, is hereby removed from the jurisdiction of the Will-South Cook Soil and Water Conservation District. 
(Ord. No. 955, § 7-1-1, 10-15-79) 
Cross reference- Planning and development, Ch. 7. 
Sec. 2-4. - Administrative citations. 
(a)  Defined. An administrative citation is a charging instrument utilized by the village to administratively process certain violations of the Code. 
(b)  Use and form generally. In lieu of filing a complaint in court, administrative citations may be issued on behalf of the village by a sworn police officer, community service officer, code enforcement officer and/or building department official for those violations of the Code identified on the village's administrative fee schedule described in subparagraph (c) below. An administrative citation shall be in the form of a "P-ticket" and shall advise the recipient of the section of the Code allegedly violated, and identify (i) the initial payment date for settlement of the claim; (ii) where payment can be made; (iii) the procedure to request a court date; and (iv) that failure to timely remit payment or request a court date shall result in an increase in the settlement amount as described in subparagraph (f) below. 
(c)  Issuance of administrative citation. Per the discretion of any police officer, community service officer, code enforcement officer and/or building department official of the village, an administrative citation may be issued for those violations of the Code identified on the administrative fee schedule. 
(d)  Administrative fee schedule. The village shall maintain an administrative fee schedule identifying those provisions of the Code for which an administrative citation may be issued and the administrative fee applicable to each such violation. The administrative fee schedule may be amended from time to time by the chief of police or his designee and shall be available to the public on the village's website and at the Plainfield Law Enforcement Center. 
(e)  Administrative fee; payment. When an administrative citation is issued, the recipient of the citation may settle and compromise the violation identified on the citation by remitting payment of the administrative fee applicable to the violation, to the village within ten (10) days of issuance of the citation (the initial pay-by date). Payment shall be made in accordance with the instructions set forth on the citation. 
(f)  Nonpayment of administrative fee. In the event payment of the administrative fee applicable to a citation is not remitted within ten (10) days of the issuance of the administrative citation, the administrative fee applicable to the citation shall, on the eleventh day after issuance of the citation, increase by twenty dollars ($20.00) unless otherwise precluded by law, and the recipient of the citation shall be granted an additional ten (10) days to remit to the village the amount then due and owing for the administrative citation. If payment is not timely remitted within ten (10) days of the issuance and/or mailing of the citation by the village in fact, final notice has been mailed, a final notice period consisting of an additional ten-day period shall ensue to allow the alleged violator a final opportunity to pay the following amounts which shall be accepted as settlement. 
(g)  Complaint or notice to appear if claim not settled; fines and penalties. If the recipient of the citation does not settle the claim within the above-described time periods, a complaint or notice to appear will be issued for the violation and the person shall be subject to the fines and penalties as set forth in the applicable provisions of this Code. 
(h)  Prima facie evidence. The fact that a vehicle illegally operated, parked or otherwise the subject of an administrative citation issued pursuant to this article is registered with the Secretary of State in the name of the alleged violator, shall be considered prima facie evidence that the alleged violator was in control of or was the operator of the vehicle at the time of the alleged violation. 
(Ord. No. 1161, §§ 1-7, 6-6-88; Ord. No. 1170, § I, 8-1-88; Ord. No. 2924, 3-1-10) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 1161, adopted June 6, 1988, did not specifically amend this Code; hence inclusion of §§ 1-7 as § 2-4 was at the discretion of the editor. The documents known as Exhibits 1 and 2, which were attached to Ord. No. 1161, are not printed herein, but are on file and available for reference along with the ordinance in the office of the village clerk. Exhibits 1 and/or 2 have been amended by the following ordinances: Ord. No. 1170, § I, 8-1-88. 
State Law reference- 5 ILCS 100/1-1 et seq.; 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1; 65 ILCS 5/1-2.1-1 et seq.; 625 ILCS 11-208.3. 
Sec. 2-5. - Fiscal year. 
(a)  The fiscal year commencing on July 1, 1989, will end April 30, 1990. 
(b)  The subsequent fiscal year shall begin on May 1, 1990, and end on April 30, 1991, and for all subsequent years the fiscal year shall begin on May 1 and end on April 30 of the following year. 
(Ord. No. 1252, §§ I, II, 5-15-89) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 1252, adopted May 15, 1989, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, inclusion of §§ I, II, as § 2-5 was at the editor's discretion. 
Sec. 2-5.1. - Acceptance of credit card payments. 
    The president and village board hereby authorizes the acceptance of credit cards for fines, fees, charges, taxes, costs or other bills owing to, collected by or imposed by the Village of Plainfield, and to adopt reasonable rules governing the manner of acceptance of payment by credit cards and to enter into such agreements with one (1) or more financial institutions or service providers as may be necessary to facilitate acceptance and process of credit card payments. 
(Ord. No. 3317, § 3, 8-7-17) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3317, § 3, adopted Aug. 7, 2017, did not specify manner of inclusion; hence, codification as § 2-5.1 was at the discretion of the editor. 
DIVISION 2. - ADOPTING PROCEDURES FOR ELECTRONIC ATTENDANCE AT MEETINGS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2765, adopted on June 3, 2008 did not specifically amend the Code. Hence, at the discretion of the editor these provisions have been included as a new division 2, §§ 2-6-2-12. See also the Code Comparative Table. 

Sec. 2-6. - Rules statement. 
    It is the decision of the President and Board of Trustees of the Village of Plainfield ("board of trustees") that any member of the board of trustees may attend any open or closed meeting of the board of trustees via electronic means (such as by telephone, video or internet connection) provided that such attendance is in compliance with these rules and any applicable laws. 
(Ord. No. 2765, 6-3-08) 
Sec. 2-7. - Prerequisites. 
    A member of the board of trustees may attend a meeting electronically if the member meets the following conditions: 
(a)  The member should notify the clerk at least twenty-four (24) hours before the meeting, unless impractical, so that necessary communications equipment can be arranged. Inability to make the necessary technical arrangements will result in denial of a request for electronic attendance. 
(b)  The member must assert one (1) of the following three (3) reasons why he or she is unable to physically attend the meeting, 
(1)  The member cannot attend because of personal illness or disability; or 
(2)  The member cannot attend because of employment purposes or the business of the Village of Plainfield; or 
(3)  The member cannot attend because of a family or other emergency. 
(Ord. No. 2765, 6-3-08) 
Sec. 2-8. - Authorization to participate. 
(a)  The clerk, after receiving the electronic attendance request, shall inform the board of trustees of the request for electronic attendance. 
(b)  After establishing that there is a quorum physically present at the meeting where a member of the board of trustees desires to attend electronically, the presiding officer shall state that (i) a notice was received by a member of the board of trustees in accordance with these rules, and (ii) the member will be deemed authorized to attend the meeting electronically unless a motion objecting to the member's electronic attendance is made, seconded, and approved by two-thirds of the members of the board of trustees physically present at the meeting. If no such motion is made and seconded or if any such motion fails to achieve the required vote by the members of the board of trustees physically present at the meeting, then the request by the member to attend the meeting electronically shall be deemed approved by the board of trustees and the presiding officer shall declare the requesting member present. After such declaration by the presiding officer, the question of a member's electronic attendance may not be reconsidered. 
(Ord. No. 2765, 6-3-08) 
Sec. 2-9. - Adequate equipment required. 
    The member participating electronically and other member of the board of trustees must be able to communicate effectively, and members of the audience must be able to hear all communications at the meeting site. Before allowing electronic attendance at any meeting, the board of trustees shall provide equipment adequate to accomplish this objective at the meeting site. 
(Ord. No. 2765, 6-3-08) 
Sec. 2-10. - Minutes. 
    Any member attending electronically shall be considered an off-site attendee and counted as present electronically for that meeting if the member is allowed to attend. The meeting minutes shall also reflect and state specifically whether each member is physically present or present by electronic means. 
(Ord. No. 2765, 6-3-08) 
Sec. 2-11. - Rights of remote member. 
    A member permitted to attend electronically will be able to express his or her comments during the meeting and participate in the same capacity as those members physically present, subject to all general meeting guidelines and procedures previously adopted and adhered to. The member attending electronically shall be heard, considered, and counted as to any vote taken. Accordingly, the name of any member attending electronically shall be called during any vote taken and his or her vote counted and recorded by the clerk and placed in the minutes for the corresponding meeting. A member attending electronically may leave a meeting and return as in the case of any member, provided the member attending electronically shall announce his or her leaving and returning. 
(Ord. No. 2765, 6-3-08) 
Sec. 2-12. - Committee, board and commissions. 
    These rules shall apply to all committees, boards and commissions established by authority of the board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 2765, 6-3-08) 
Secs. 2-13-2-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES GENERALLY 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-20. - Salary of president and trustees. 
(a)  President . The annual salary of the village president shall be twenty-four thousand dollars ($24,000.00) payable in regular installments. This increase shall apply to the village president elected in the April 2017 election. 
(b)  Trustees. The trustees shall be paid one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each scheduled, special, workshop, and committee of the whole meeting attended. This increase shall initially apply only to trustees elected in the April 2005 elections beginning with the first meeting of their term. Trustees elected in the April 2007 elections shall also be paid one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each scheduled, special, workshop, and committee of the whole meeting attended beginning with their first meeting of their term. 
(Ord. No. 1199, §§ I, II, 1-23-89; Ord. No. 1201, §§ I, II, 1-23-89; Ord. No. 1822, § 1, 11-12-98; Ord. No. 1887, § 1, 10-4-99; Ord. No. 2247, § 1, 8-18-03; Ord. No. 2248, § 1, 8-18-03; Ord. No. 2996, § 1, 7-18-11; Ord. No. 3277, § 1, 9-19-16) 
Sec. 2-21. - Expenses. 
(a)  Each trustee and the village clerk shall be entitled to reimbursement in an amount not to exceed one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) annually for expenses incurred by each trustee and the village clerk when incurred in the course of their duties as trustee and as village clerk, without prior board approval. 
(b)  The president shall be entitled to reimbursement in an amount not to exceed three hundred dollars ($300.00) annually for reimbursement for expenses incurred by the president in the course of duties as president of the board of trustees, without prior board approval. 
(c)  As a condition of any of the above reimbursements, all expenses shall be accompanied by documentary evidence substantiating such expenses. 
(Ord. No. 1123, §§ 2-7-3-2-7-5, 4-20-87) 
Sec. 2-22. - Officers generally. 
(a)  All officers of the village, except such as are elected, shall be appointed by the president with the consent of the board on the first regular meeting of the board in May of each year, or as soon thereafter as may be practical, and as often as any vacancies may occur in any of such appointments. 
(b)  Such officers shall consist of a treasurer, a collector, a village attorney and police officers. The president, with the consent of the board, may also, from time to time, appoint such other officers as may be deemed necessary, for such term as they may see fit. 
(c)  Every officer of the village, except trustees, shall, before entering upon the duties of his office, give a bond to the village in such sum as the board may direct by resolution or ordinance, with two (2) or more sufficient sureties, or any surety company authorized by law to sign bonds, to be approved by the board. The payments for such bonds shall be made by the village. 
(d)  Each officer, besides the specific duties which he may be required to do by this Code or other ordinance, shall perform such additional duties and be subject to such other rules and regulations as the board shall, from time to time, adopt. 
(e)  The board may, from time to time, discontinue any office created by it, may discontinue the term of service of any officer appointed to any office, and may transfer the duties of any such office or officer so discontinued to any other office or officer of the village. 
(Ord. of 10-25-01; Code 1973, Ch. 1, § 2-2) 
State Law reference- Appointment of village officers, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 3-8-1. 
Sec. 2-23. - Personal use of police and emergency utility repair vehicles. 
    All village marked police department vehicles and all village trucks used to carry and store emergency utility repair equipment are prohibited from being operated for the personal use of any employee, other than driving the vehicle from the work place to home and from home back again to the work place. 
(Ord. No. 1090, § 2-10-1, 8-5-85) 
Cross reference- Utilities, Ch. 8. 
Sec. 2-24. - Retirement fund-Participation of village. 
    The village hereby elects to participate in the Illinois Municipal Retirement Fund, effective January 1, 1977. 
(Ord. No. 880, § 6-1-1, 9-20-76) 
State Law reference- Illinois Municipal Retirement Fund, 40 ILCS 5/7-101 et seq. 
Sec. 2-25. - Same-Participation of president, trustees and clerk. 
    The village president, village trustees and village clerk require service of six hundred (600) or more hours per year. The above-listed officials may become participating members of the Illinois Municipal Retirement Fund, under the rules and regulations of said fund, should any of them elect to do so. 
(Ord. No. 881, §§ 6-2-1, 6-2-2, 9-20-76) 
Sec. 2-26. - Inauguration date for newly elected officers. 
    The time for inauguration of newly elected officers for the village shall commence at the first regular or special meeting of the corporate authorities in the month of May following such election. 
(Ord. No. 1361, 4-8-91) 
Sec. 2-27. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2402, § 1, adopted May 17, 2004, repealed § 2-27, which pertained to State Gift Ban Act and derived from Ord. No. 1859, § 1(A-101-A-106), adopted June 21, 1999. 
Secs. 2-28-2-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Residence of municipal officers, 65 ILCS 5/3-14-1; interest of municipal officers in contract, work, business or sales of municipality, 65 ILCS 5/3-14-4. 

Sec. 2-41. - Creation of office; appointment; term. 
    The office of village administrator is created. The village administrator shall be appointed by the president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees for an indefinite term as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 1034, § 2-8, 6-7-82) 
State Law reference- Appointment of village officers, 65 ILCS 5/3-8-1. 
Sec. 2-42. - Qualifications; removal. 
    The village administrator shall be chosen on the basis of his executive and administrative qualifications, with particular reference to his actual experience or in his knowledge of accepted practices in respect to the duties of his office. At the time of his appointment, he need not be an actual resident of the village or the state, provided that he shall become a resident of the village within one (1) year after the date of his appointment unless the president and board of trustees waive the requirement of local residency by contract, or otherwise in writing. The village administrator may be removed from office at any time by a majority vote of the president and board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 1034, § 2-8-1, 6-7-82; Ord. No. 1116, § 2-8-1, 8-18-86) 
Sec. 2-43. - Powers and duties. 
    The village administrator shall have all powers and duties assigned to him by statute and such other authority as may be granted by the president and board of trustees. The village administrator shall exercise these specific duties: 
(1)  Control. The village administrator shall exercise control over all village departments and subdivisions thereof that may be created by the board of trustees. He may recommend to the president and board of trustees the appointment of all officers and other department heads of the village, except the police chief, including those who are required by law to be appointed by the president and board of trustees voting jointly, and those who are required to be appointed by the president. He shall recommend the removal or suspension of any officer or employee when such removal or suspension shall be consistent with the best interests of the village. All recommendations for appointment or removal shall be based on merit and qualifications or disqualifications of such officer or employee without regard to political belief or affiliation. He may recommend to the board of trustees the salaries, wages, hours, and conditions of employment of all officers and employees under his jurisdiction. Nothing in this section shall limit the board of trustees from making the final decision as to the persons employed or the amount of their salaries or wages. 
(2)  Recommendations and advice. The village administrator shall recommend to the board of trustees the adoption of such measures as he may deem necessary or expedient. He shall advise the board of trustees of the financial condition of the village and the future financial needs of the village, and make such recommendations as he deems appropriate. 
(3)  Annual financial report. The village administrator shall prepare and submit to the president and board of trustees at the conclusion of the fiscal year or at any other time deemed appropriate by the aforementioned officials, a complete report of the financial and administrative activities of the village for the preceding fiscal year. 
(4)  Annual budget. The village administrator shall prepare or cause to be prepared an annual budget and shall submit the budget to the president and board of trustees together with a message outlining its important features on or before the second board of trustees meeting in the month of May. He shall be responsible for its administration after adoption, provided that nothing in this section shall limit the duties and responsibilities of the village treasurer as provided for in state statutes and the ordinances of this village. 
(5)  Attendance at meetings. The village administrator shall attend all the regular and special meetings of the board of trustees, unless expressly excused by the board. 
(6)  Purchases. The village administrator shall purchase all materials, supplies, and equipment for which funds are provided in the budget, provided that no purchase shall be made, contract let, or obligation incurred for any item or service which exceeds the current budget appropriation without a supplemental appropriation by the board of trustees. The authority of the village administrator to authorize purchase orders or contracts or to expend the funds of the village shall be limited to five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). The village administrator shall make recommendations to the president and board of trustees as to whether a bid or contract offer is desirable or undesirable, or which of several contracts or bids submitted to the village is the most desirable. The village administrator shall provide a written monthly report to the president and board of trustees of all expenditures in excess of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00). 
(7)  Investigation of complaints. The village administrator shall investigate all complaints in relation to matters concerning the administration of the government of the village and services maintained by the public utilities in the village and shall see that all franchises, permits, and privileges created by the village are faithfully observed. 
(8)  Absence or vacancy of treasurer. The village administrator during any period of absence or vacancy of the village treasurer shall immediately assume the duties and exercise the full powers of the office as provided for in the village ordinances and state statutes. In no event shall the village administrator be required to obtain a bond in his capacity as acting treasurer if at the time of the exercise of such duties he has a bond in effect in an amount not less than the amount of the treasurer's bond. 
(9)  Checks. The village administrator shall be designated as the alternate signer of all village checks. 
(Ord. No. 1034, § 2-8-3, 6-7-82; Ord. No. 1578, § 1, 8-1-94) 
State Law reference- Vacancy in office of treasurer, 65 ILCS 5/3-4-2. 
Sec. 2-44. - Conflict of interest. 
    The village administrator shall not be interested directly or indirectly in any contract, work, or business of the village; or in the sale of any article to the village; or in the purchase of any property belonging to the village, or sold for taxes or assessments, or sold by virtue of legal processes by the suit of the village. 
(Ord. No. 1034, § 2-8-5, 6-7-82) 
Sec. 2-45. - Powers of president and board of trustees. 
    All functions, powers, and duties conferred or imposed on the village administrator shall be subject to the superior right and power of the president and board of trustees to supervise and administer the local government and affairs of the village. However, all acts and things done by the village administrator pursuant to the provisions in this division shall, unless otherwise expressly provided herein, be final and conclusive unless and until superseded by the action of the president and board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 1034, § 2-8-6, 6-7-82) 
Secs. 2-46-2-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - VILLAGE CLERK[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Recordation of ordinances, record as prima facie evidence, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-5; duties of village clerk, 65 ILCS 5/3-10-7. 

Sec. 2-61. - Generally. 
    The village clerk shall be the keeper of the village seal. Such seal shall be used by the clerk and the president in all cases that have been or shall be provided by the laws of the United States, the laws of the respective states of the United States, and the ordinances of the village, and in all cases in which by the laws and customs of nations it is necessary to use a seal by a corporation. The clerk shall also have the custody of and safely keep all public records, documents, ordinances, resolutions and orders of the board and such other papers and documents as may be delivered into his custody. 
(Ord. of 10-25-01; Code 1973, Ch. 1, §§ 2-1-2, 2-5-1) 
Sec. 2-62. - Board meetings; warrants; publication of reports. 
    The village clerk shall attend all meetings of the board and keep a full record of its proceedings in the journal. He shall prepare all warrants for the payment of money; countersign and deliver the same when called for, after they have been registered by the treasurer, taking a proper receipt for the same. The village clerk shall publish, as required by the village charter or state statute, the treasurer's and collector's annual report filed with him between the first and tenth of April of each year. 
(Ord. of 10-25-01; Code 1973, Ch. 1, § 2-5-2) 
Editor's note- Although the village was created by the granting of a charter, the powers and responsibilities of the village are generally governed by the Illinois Statutes. 
State Law reference- Incorporation of municipalities generally, 65-ILCS 5/2-1-1 et seq.; incorporation of villages, 65 ILCS 5/2-3-1 et seq.; publication of treasurer's annual account, 65 ILCS 5/3-10-5.1; publication of collector's annual report, 65 ILCS 5/3-11-26. 
Sec. 2-63. - Recording ordinances. 
    All ordinances passed by the board shall be recorded by the clerk in a book to be kept for that purpose before the next regular meeting after their passage. The clerk shall note at the foot of the record of each ordinance a memorandum of the date of its passage, the date of its approval by the president and the date of the publication of such ordinance, which record and memorandum or a certified copy thereof shall be prima facie evidence of the passage and legal publication of such ordinance. The original shall be filed in the office of the clerk with a certificate of publication attached to the ordinances requiring publication. 
(Ord. of 10-25-01; Code 1973, Ch. 1, § 2-5-3) 
Sec. 2-64. - Filing of appropriation ordinance with county clerk. 
    On or before the second Tuesday in August in each year, the clerk shall file with the county clerk a certified copy of an ordinance in which the total amount of appropriation for all corporate purposes of the village, legally made, are levied and assessed. 
(Ord. of 10-25-01; Code 1973, Ch. 1, § 2-5-5) 
Sec. 2-65. - Assessment records. 
    The village clerk shall file in his office all assessment rolls and judgments certified by a clerk of a court of record against property within the village and shall issue a warrant to the village collector for the collection of such assessment. The assessment warrant shall contain a copy of such certificate of the judgment, describing the lots, blocks, tracts, or parcels of land assessed, and the respective amounts assessed on each lot, block, tract or parcel of land, and shall be delivered to the village collector. Such warrant shall give sufficient authority to collect the assessments therein specified. 
(Ord. of 10-25-01; Code 1973, Ch. 1, § 2-5-6) 
Sec. 2-66. - Responsibility for Code. 
(a)  The village clerk shall be responsible for the maintenance of this Code and shall at all times keep up-to-date three (3) copies hereof, one (1) of which shall be available for public use during the regular business hours of the clerk's office. 
(b)  The maintenance that the village clerk is responsible for shall take place immediately after the passage and approval of any additional or amending ordinance and shall consist of the following: 
(1)  Type on an "Additional Table of Contents" page, designated for the chapter and heading as shown on the new ordinance, the complete article number, heading or title and the date of passage of the new ordinance. 
(2)  Place the new ordinance in the books under the proper chapter, article and section number in sequence as designated on the new ordinance. 
(3)  Remove any old ordinance that was repealed by the new ordinance and strike out the repealed ordinance from the original table of contents and type thereon the date repealed and the chapter, article and section number of the new ordinance. 
(c)  The village clerk shall, every twelve (12) months, retype the entire Table of Contents so as to include in sequence under their proper chapter, article and section number, the various ordinances passed during the previous twelve (12) months. The clerk shall make an Additional Table of Contents page for each of the various chapters in the book. Each additional ordinance page shall contain at the top the specific chapter to which it refers, and those additional ordinance pages shall be placed at the rear of the Table of Contents to allow for inclusion thereon of additional ordinances to be passed in the succeeding twelve-month period as directed in paragraph (b)(1). 
(Code 1973, Ch. 1, §§ 3-1-3-3) 
Sec. 2-67. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1512, § 1, adopted May 3, 1993, repealed § 2-67, which pertained to the salary of the village clerk. See the Code Comparative Table. 
Sec. 2-68. - Deputy. 
    The village clerk may appoint a deputy clerk. 
(Ord. No. 1038, § 3-6-4, 11-1-82) 
DIVISION 3.5. - MANAGEMENT SERVICES DEPARTMENT 

Sec. 2-69. - Creation of department. 
    There is hereby created and established the management services department which shall be under the jurisdiction and control of the village administrator. 
(Ord. No. 1756, § 1, 9-22-97; Ord. No. 2170, § 1, 11-18-02) 
Sec. 2-70. - Appointment, term and removal of director. 
    The supervisor of the management services department shall be the director of the management services department. Said director shall be appointed by the president and board of trustees upon the recommendation of the village administrator and shall serve as director until removed from such position. 
(Ord. No. 1756, § 1, 9-22-97; Ord. No. 2170, § 1, 11-18-02) 
Sec. 2-71. - Jurisdiction. 
    The management services department shall encompass the financial functions of the village including the work of the comptroller, village treasurer and budget officer. 
(Ord. No. 1756, § 1, 9-22-97; Ord. No. 2170, § 1, 11-18-02) 
Sec. 2-72. - Duties of director. 
    The director of management services department shall have the following duties, responsibilities and functions: 
(a)  To supervise the department employees and the village comptroller, if any. 
(b)  To supervise the village treasury. 
(c)  To maintain all accounting records and reports as to village finances in accordance with applicable law and generally accepted accounting principles. 
(d)  To report at least monthly on financial matters to the village administrator. 
(e)  To establish all procedures relating to the collection, encumbrance and disbursement of the village's funds. 
(f)  To make recommendations to the village administrator as to the financial condition of the village and to make suggestions as to its improvement. 
(g)  To maintain an inventory of real and personal property owned or leased by the village together with tax exemption records thereof. 
(h)  To supervise all other offices of the village insofar as they relate to the collection or disbursement of village funds. 
(i)  To supervise all duties and responsibilities charged to the village collector. 
(j)  To act as village budget officer if designated as such by the village administrator. If the director is so designated as budget officer, the director shall perform the following duties, responsibilities and functions: 
(1)  To permit and encourage the use of efficient planning, budgeting, auditing, reporting, accounting and other fiscal management procedures. 
(2)  To compile a budget in accordance with the following, which budget shall contain estimates of revenues available to the village for the fiscal year for which the budget is drafted, together with recommended expenditures for the village and all of the village's departments, commissions and boards: 
a.  The budget shall be itemized in a manner consistent with a chart of accounts as may now or in the future be approved by the auditor of public accounts of the State of Illinois. 
b.  The budget shall contain actual or estimated revenues and expenditures for the two (2) years immediately preceding the fiscal year for which the budget is prepared. So far as is possible, the fiscal data for such two (2) preceding fiscal years shall be itemized in a form consistent with the chart of accounts approved by the auditors of public accounts for the State of Illinois. 
c.  Each budget shall show the specific fund from which each anticipated expenditure shall be made. 
(3)  Expenditures for the capital improvements shall be budgeted in the fiscal year in which the capital improvement will occur. 
(4)  Upon the completion or abandonment of any object for which the capital improvement fund, or should any surplus moneys remain after the completion or abandonment of any object for which the capital improvement fund was inaugurated, then such funds no longer necessary for capital improvement shall be transferred into the fund of the originating revenue source on the first day of the fiscal year following such abandonment, completion or discovery of such funds. 
(5)  To examine all books and records of all village department, commissions and boards, which relate to monies received by the village, village departments, commissions and boards, and paid out by the village, village departments, commissions and boards, debts and accounts receivable, amounts owed by or to the village, village departments, commissions and boards. 
(6)  To obtain such additional information from the village, village departments, commissions and boards as may be useful to the budget officer for purposes of compiling a village budget, such information to be furnished by the village, village departments, commissions and boards in the form required by the budget officer. Any department, commission or board which refuses to make such information as is requested of it available to the budget officer shall not be permitted to make expenditures under any subsequent budget for the village until such village department, commission or board shall comply in full with the request of the budget officer. 
(7)  To establish and maintain such procedures as shall insure that no expenditures are made by the village, village departments, commissions or boards except as authorized by the budget. 
(8)  Upon the written authorization of the village administrator to make transfers between or among accounts within the same department or between or among departments within the same fund. The authority to make such transfers need only be granted once and shall extend until revoked, in writing, by the village administrator. Any budget revision that would increase the total expenditures for any fund may only be accomplished by a budget amendment approved by the village board. The village administrator shall be notified in writing of any interdepartmental transfer within a fund. 
(k)  To perform such duties as may be required from time to time by the village administrator. 
(Ord. No. 1756, § 1, 9-22-97; Ord. No. 2170, § 1, 11-18-02) 
Sec. 2-73. - Budget system enacted. 
    The Village of Plainfield adopts and makes a part hereof 65 Illinois Complied Statutes 5/8-2-9.1 through 5/8-2-9.10 which provides that a municipality, by a vote of two-thirds of the corporate authorities then holding office, may provide for a budget officer having the responsibility to complete an annual budget in lieu of an annual appropriation ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 1772, 1-19-98) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1772 did not specifically amend the Code and has been included herein at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 2-74-2-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - VILLAGE TREASURER[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal treasurer, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 3-10-1 et seq.; bond of treasurer, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 3-14-3. 

Sec. 2-81. - Generally. 
    The village treasurer, from time to time, shall take under his charge and keep a true and correct account of all money belonging to the village, stating from whom and on what account received. He shall give two (2) receipts therefor to the person from whom he may receive the same, one (1) of which receipts the person to whom the treasurer may give them shall deliver to the village clerk in order that the treasurer may be charged by the village clerk with the amount thereof. In no case shall any officer of the village, or any other person, be released from his responsibility to the village for any money he may at any time have in his possession belonging to the village, until he shall deliver to the village clerk the treasurer's receipt. 
(Ord. of 10-25-01; Code 1973, Ch. 1, § 2-6-2) 
Sec. 2-82. - Reports. 
    The village treasurer shall on the first of each month, or more often, if required, make a report to the board of the amount of money received by him, paid out, and on hand, and shall at the close of each fiscal year make out and deliver to the village clerk a full and complete report of his doings during the preceding year, stating the amount of money received and from whom and for what purpose received, and exhibit all credits allowed by law and the ordinances of the village. 
(Ord. of 10-25-01; Code 1973, Ch. 1, § 2-6-3) 
Sec. 2-83. - Salary. 
    The compensation of the village treasurer shall be two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) per year, payable in equal monthly installments. 
(Ord. No. 694, 2-17-69; Code 1973, Ch. 1, § 2-7-2) 
Secs. 2-84-2-95. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - VILLAGE ATTORNEY 

Sec. 2-96. - General duties. 
    The village attorney shall appear for the village in all cases wherein the village is a party, in all courts; shall give legal opinions when required upon any subject submitted to him by the president or the board; draft ordinances, contracts, deeds, bonds and all other legal papers; and shall act as the legal adviser of the president, the board and committees thereof in all matters pertaining to the village. 
(Ord. of 10-25-01; Code 1973, Ch. 1, § 2-4-1) 
Sec. 2-97. - Attending meetings of board of trustees. 
    The village attorney shall attend the meetings of the board when required. 
(Ord. of 10-25-01; Code 1973, Ch. 1, § 2-4-1) 
Secs. 2-98-2-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - VILLAGE COLLECTOR[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal collector, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 3-11-25 et seq. 

Sec. 2-111. - Generally. 
    The village collector shall hold his office from the date of his qualification until the first Monday in May thereafter or until his successor shall be appointed and qualified. He shall collect all special assessment and other warrants which by law and the ordinances of the village may be executed by such officer. 
(Ord. of 10-25-01; Code 1973, Ch. 1, § 2-3-3) 
Sec. 2-112. - Records generally; disposition of funds. 
    The collector shall preserve all warrants which are returned into his hands, and he shall keep such books and his accounts in such manner as the president and board of trustees may by resolution prescribe. Such warrants, books and all papers pertaining to his office shall at all times be open to the inspection of and subject to the examination of the president, the village clerk or any member of the board of trustees or committee thereof. Each week, or more often if required by the president and board of trustees, he shall pay over to the treasurer all moneys collected, taking the treasurer's receipt therefor. He shall file such receipt immediately with the village clerk, but the village clerk shall at the same time or on demand give the collector a copy of the receipt so filed. 
(Ord. of 10-25-01; Code 1973, Ch. 1, § 2-3-5) 
Sec. 2-113. - Collection duties and records generally. 
    The collector shall collect all special assessments and special tax warrants issued by any court of competent jurisdiction for the collection of any special assessment or special tax levied and assessed on property within the corporate limits of the village. He shall keep a true, full and complete record of all warrants returned to him and all moneys by him received on account thereof, and of all moneys paid over by him to the village treasurer. 
(Ord. of 10-25-01; Code 1973, Ch. 1, § 2-3-6) 
Sec. 2-114. - Notice of warrant for special tax or assessment. 
    In all cases where a warrant for the collection of a special assessment or a special tax shall come to the hands of the collector, he shall immediately give notice thereof by publishing a notice in one (1) or more newspapers in the village if such newspaper is there, and if not, by posting four (4) copies thereof in public along the line of the prospective improvement. The form of such notice shall be designated by the board. When such assessments or special tax is levied to be paid in installments such notice shall contain the amount of each installment, the rate of interest that deferred installments bear and the date when payable. 
(Ord. of 10-25-01; Code 1973, Ch. 1, § 2-3-7) 
Sec. 2-115. - Additional notice to persons liable; record of payment. 
    The collector into whose hands the warrant shall come shall, as far as practicable, call upon all persons resident within the neighborhood whose names appear upon the assessment roll or the occupants of the property and personally or by written or printed notices left at their places of abode, informing them of such special assessment and request payment of the same. If the collector omits to do so, the validity of the special assessment or right to apply for and obtain judgment thereon shall not be affected by such omission. The collector shall write the word "paid" opposite each tract or lot on which the assessment is paid, together with the name and post office address of the person making the payment and the date of payment. 
(Ord. of 10-25-01; Code 1973, Ch. 1, § 2-3-8) 
Sec. 2-116. - Delinquent assessments. 
    The collector, on or before the first day of April in each year, shall make a report in writing to the general officer of the county authorized or designated by the general revenue laws of this state to apply for judgment and sell lands for taxes due the county and the state, of all the land, town lots and real property on which he shall be unable to collect special assessments or installments thereof, matured and payable, or interest thereon due on installment not yet matured, on all warrants in his hands, with the amount of such delinquent special assessment or installments and interest together with his warrants; or in case of an assessment levied, to be paid by installments, with a brief description of the nature of the warrant or warrants received by him authorizing the collection thereof, which report shall be accompanied with the oath of the collector that the list is a correct return and report of the lands, town lots and real property upon which the special assessment or special tax levied by the authority of the village, or installments thereof or interest remaining due and unpaid; that he is unable to collect the same or any part thereof and that he has given the notice required by law that such warrants have been received by him for collection. 
(Ord. of 10-25-01; Code 1973, Ch. 1, § 2-3-9) 
State Law reference- Delinquent taxes, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 120, § 705 et seq.; sale of real property for delinquent taxes, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 120, § 710 et seq. 
Sec. 2-117. - Reports. 
    The collector shall make a report in writing to the president or any officer designated by the president and board of trustees of all amounts collected by him, the account whereon collected or of any other matter in connection with his office when required so to do by resolution or ordinance duly adopted and passed by the president and board of trustees. He shall also between the first and tenth day of April of each year file with the village clerk a statement of all the money collected by him during the year, the particular warrant, special assessment or account on which collected, the balance of money uncollected on all warrants in his hands and the balance remaining uncollected at the time of the return on all warrants which he shall have returned during the preceding fiscal year to the village clerk. The village clerk shall immediately cause the report to be published in a newspaper printed in the village if there is one and if not, by posting the same in a public place in the clerk's office. 
(Ord. of 10-25-01; Code 1973, Ch. 1, § 2-3-10) 
Sec. 2-118. - Withholding village funds. 
    The collector shall not keep the money of the village in his hands or in the hands of any person to his use beyond the time which may be prescribed for the payment of the same to the treasurer. Any violation of this provision shall subject him to immediate removal from office. 
(Ord. of 10-25-01; Code 1973, Ch. 1, § 2-3-11) 
Secs. 2-119-2-130. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - VILLAGE PLANNER[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- Planning and development, Ch. 7. 
State Law reference- Authority of municipalities that have created a plan commission or planning department, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 11-12-4. 

Sec. 2-131. - Position created. 
    There is hereby created the position of planner for the village. 
(Ord. No. 1134, § 2, 9-21-87) 
Sec. 2-132. - Duties and powers-Generally. 
    The village planner shall provide administrative and technical assistance to the village plan commission, as well as the president and board of trustees, in the exercise of those powers set forth in section 11-12-5 of the Illinois Municipal Code, as well as those duties and powers set forth in section 2-173 of this Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 1134, § 2-1, 9-21-87) 
State Law reference- General powers of plan commissions, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 11-12-5. 
Sec. 2-133. - Same-Specific responsibilities. 
    The village planner shall provide assistance and information on matters pertaining to the growth and development of the village and shall be responsible for major planning projects, the processing of zoning petitions, review of all subdivision proposals, and other similar matters, to insure compliance with all village ordinances. Further duties include responsibility for conducting routine inspections to insure compliance with the village's zoning regulations, and conferring with landowners, developers, commercial and business representatives and village officials with regard to planning projects. Other responsibilities shall include research in working with regional, local, and statewide planning agencies and organizations and performing such other tasks as may be directed by the president and board of trustees, the village plan commission, and the village administrator. 
(Ord. No. 1134, § 2-2, 9-21-87) 
Sec. 2-134. - Conflict of interest. 
    The village planner shall not have any pecuniary interest, directly or indirectly, in any contract, work, or business of the village or in the sale of any article to the village or in the purchase of any property belonging to the village. The village planner shall devote all time, attention and energies to the village's business and shall not, during such employment, be engaged in any other business, teaching or consulting activity, whether or not such activity is pursued for gain, profit or other pecuniary advantage, without the express prior approval of the president and board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 1134, § 2-3, 9-21-87) 
Secs. 2-135-2-140. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - CODE OFFICIAL AND BUILDING INSPECTOR[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 1270, adopted Aug. 7, 1989, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion of §§ 1-3 as §§ 2-141-2-143 of a new Div. 8 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 2.5; office of building inspector, § 2.5-23. 

Sec. 2-141. - Position created. 
    There is hereby created the position of code official and building inspector for the village. 
Sec. 2-142. - Duties and powers. 
    The code official and building inspector shall be responsible for securing compliance with building and zoning codes and related regulations, including inspecting the construction of buildings, additions and alterations to insure compliance with building and zoning ordinances, reviewing requests for and issuing building permits, and conferring with contractors and property owners to enforce municipal and state building codes. In addition, other duties shall include, but not be limited to, interpreting regulations and codes to builders and property owners and assisting them in altering construction plans to meet established standards and to recommend and propose amendments to the building code to comply with legislative and technical changes. The code official and building inspector shall also act as a technical advisor to various committees, boards and village officials on matters related to municipal building and related codes and ordinances. Other responsibilities include assisting in court proceedings to enforce village ordinances, inspect businesses and other occupancies to verify compliance order discontinuance of illegal uses, assisting in maintaining all zoning records including master zoning maps, amendments, special use permits, variances, and appeals and to supervise the work of the building, electrical, and plumbing inspectors, and performing the tasks that may be directed by the president and board of trustees, village administrator and the village planner. 
(Ord. No. 1270, § 2, 8-7-89) 
Sec. 2-143. - Conflict of interest; other employment. 
    The code official and building inspector shall not have any pecuniary interest, directly or indirectly, in any contract, work, or business of the village or in the sale of any article to the village or in the purchase of any property belonging to the village. In addition, the code official and building inspector shall not have any pecuniary interest whatsoever, including any investment, or beneficial interest, in any real estate in the village or within one and one-half (11/2) miles of the village corporate limits. The employee shall devote all time, attention and energies to the village's business and shall not, during such employment be engaged in any other business, teaching or consulting activity, whether or not such activity is pursued for gain, profit or other pecuniary advantage, without the express prior approval of the president and board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 1270, § 3, 8-7-89) 
Secs. 2-144-2-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-151-2-165. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PLAN COMMISSION[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3115, adopted June 17, 2013, amended div. 2 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former div. 2, §§ 2-166-2-175, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 523, adopted April 1, 1957; Ord. No. 741, adopted March 6, 1972; the Code of 1973, Ch. 7, § 1-1; and Ord. No. 1102, §§ 1-1-1-5, adopted March 17, 1986. 
Cross reference- Planning and development, Ch. 7. 
State Law reference- Plan commissions, Ill. Rev. Stat. Ch. 24, § 11-12-4 et seq. 

Sec. 2-166. - Created. 
    A plan commission is hereby created. 
(Ord. No. 3115, 6-17-13) 
Sec. 2-167. - Membership generally. 
    There shall be seven (7) members of the plan commission. Each member shall be appointed by the village president and confirmed by the board of trustees. The village president shall nominate persons for membership on the commission. 
(Ord. No. 3115, 6-17-13) 
Sec. 2-168. - Terms of members. 
(a)  All appointments of members of the plan commission shall be for three-year staggered terms and shall be made at the first meeting in May. No member of the plan commission shall be related in any manner to village employees. 
(b)  Members of the commission shall serve until their successors have been duly appointed and qualified. Appointments to fill a vacancy shall be for the remainder of the unexpired terms. 
(c)  All members of the commission shall be residents of the Village of Plainfield. 
(Ord. No. 3115, 6-17-13) 
Sec. 2-169. - Officers. 
    The village president, with the consent of the board of trustees, shall appoint at the first meeting in May of each year a chairman and a vice-chairman of the plan commission. The terms of officers shall begin the day after the first regular meeting of the board of trustees in May. Officers shall hold office for a term of one (1) year and may succeed themselves. The village board shall supply a secretary to the commission. 
(Ord. No. 3115, 6-17-13) 
Sec. 2-170. - Secretary. 
    The secretary of the plan commission shall be a nonmember thereof and shall have no vote. 
(Ord. No. 3115, 6-17-13) 
Sec. 2-171. - Operating procedures. 
    The plan commission shall adopt such operating procedures as it from time to time may deem proper and necessary. The adoption and amendment of such procedures shall be by a majority vote of all the members of the commission; provided, however, that every member of the commission shall be furnished a copy of such proposed procedures and amendments thereto at least five (5) days before consideration thereof for adoption. 
(Ord. No. 3115, 6-17-13) 
Sec. 2-172. - Powers. 
(a)  The plan commission shall continue all work in progress of the previous plan commission or properly filed for the consideration of the plan commission. The commission shall have such powers as are enumerated in section 11-12-5 of the Illinois Municipal Code and all other powers from time to time given such commission by the state statutes. In addition thereto, the commission shall prepare and recommend for consideration and adoption by the board of trustees, the following: 
(1)  A statement of goals and objectives to help guide growth and development in the village and its environs; 
(2)  A comprehensive plan for the present and future development and redevelopment of the village. Such plan may be adopted in whole or in separate geographical or functional parts, each of which, when adopted by the board of trustees, shall be the official comprehensive plan or part thereof; 
(3)  Such amendments to the comprehensive plan as may be deemed necessary; and 
(4)  An official map of the village and such later revisions in such map as may be deemed necessary by the board of trustees or by the commission. 
(b)  The commission shall also: 
(1)  Prepare and recommend to the board of trustees from time to time plans and specific improvements in pursuance of the official comprehensive plan; 
(2)  Give aid to other officers of the village charged with the direction of improvements embraced within the official comprehensive plan, to further the making of such improvements, and generally to promote realization of such plan; 
(3)  Call upon any officers of the village for aid and advise upon any matter properly within the scope of interest of the commission; and give aid to the officers of the village and other governmental agencies charged with the direction of projects for improvements included in the official map, to further the making of such improvements and generally to promote the realization of the official comprehensive plan. If the commission deems it advisable to secure technical assistance or service, it may do so upon authority from and within appropriations made by, the board of trustees; 
(4)  Consult with municipal and county regional planning commissions, state planning agencies, and the Northeastern Illinois Metropolitan Area Planning Commission to the end that coordinated planning for the village, county and metropolitan area will be encouraged; 
(5)  Conduct public hearings for all requested amendments to the zoning ordinance, whether initiated by the village or by a private individual or corporation. The commission shall submit its report, findings of fact and recommendations for action to the board of trustees for its consideration; 
(6)  Conduct public hearings for such special uses as may be requested by the village or by a private individual or corporation. The commission shall submit its report, findings of fact and recommendations for action to the board of trustees for its consideration; 
(7)  Review all land use and site plans presented to the village for review at the time of annexation or anytime thereafter and all plats of subdivision submitted for approval on properties located within the village limits and in territory within one and one-half (11/2) miles of the village limits; and 
(8)  Exercise such other powers germane to the powers granted by state statutes and this division as may from time to time be conferred on the commission by the board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 3115, 6-17-13) 
Sec. 2-173. - Salary of chairman and commissioners. 
(a)  Chairman. The chairman shall be paid thirty dollars ($30.00) for each scheduled or special meeting attended. 
(b)  Commissioner. The commissioners shall be paid twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each scheduled or special meeting attended. 
(Ord. No. 3115, 6-17-13) 
Sec.2-174. Record - of proceedings. 
    The plan commission shall keep a written record of its proceeding, which shall be open to public inspection during regular business hours. 
(Ord. No. 3115, 6-17-13) 
Sec. 2-175. - Annual report. 
    The plan commission shall submit an annual report to the board of trustees not later than July first of each year. 
(Ord. No. 3115, 6-17-13) 
Secs. 2-176-2-185. - Reserved.
