(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06; Ord. No. 2722, § 1, 12-17-07) 
Secs. 2.5-287-2.5-300. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - STANDARD FOR STREET NAME ASSIGNMENT 

Sec. 2.5-301. - Pronunciation. 
    Street names shall be easy to pronounce and read in order for the public, children in particular, to easily speak the street name in an emergency situation. For the same reason, street names with confusing spellings shall likewise be avoided. 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-302. - Appropriate. 
    Street names shall not be considered inappropriate in regards to race, color, sex, religion, national origin, ancestry, disability, or regarded as generally offensive such as Death Row St., Squaw Ln., or Redskin Rd. 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-303. - Confusing or generic streets. 
    Common sense shall be used when selecting street names to avoid implementing confusing or generic names such as the following: 
 Dead End Rd. 
 Gravel Rd. 
 Private St. 
 Cross Rd. 
 Frontage Rd. 
 Scenic Dr. 
 Access Rd. 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-304. - Similar sounding streets. 
    Street names shall not duplicate or sound similar to other street names even in cases where the spelling is unique. Pearce and Pierce are not acceptable, nor shall Springdale and Springdell be allowed. It is not acceptable to merely change the street type if the root street name is the same, with the special exceptions of place, circle and court. For example, Oak Road, Oak Lane and Oak Street cannot all be utilized. However, using both Oak Road and Oak Court is acceptable, as long as Oak Court extends from Oak Road. Further explanation of the proper use of place, circle and court are covered in Divisions 6 and 10 of this article. Proposed names shall also be rejected if one of the principal words in the name has already been used several times (i.e. Meadow, View or Wood). 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-305. - Street name length. 
    Street names shall be fourteen (14) characters or less, exclusive of prefixes and suffixes. Spaces between words shall be counted as characters. When the prefix and type are added to a long street name, the letters on the street sign will usually be smaller in appearance. Governments do not normally want to incur the cost to produce a larger street sign to accommodate the long street name. Safety problems can arise due to being able to read smaller letters on a sign. 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-306. - Street name spacing. 
    Street names shall be no more than two (2) words and unnecessary spacing in a name shall be avoided. For example, Forestview is much preferred over Forest View. A two-word street name is often compressed into one-word on a street sign to conserve space. This compression often misleads the public into believing that the street sign is the official name. 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-307. - Numeric street names. 
    Numeric street names shall be written using numbers rather than spelled out as words. Additionally, numeric street names shall include the TH, RD, ST or ND characters as part of the street name. For example, 3RD shall be used instead of THIRD or 3. 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-308. - Abbreviations and punctuation. 
    Street name, type, directional prefix, unit and subunit types shall all be capitalized in the master address database. Elements of a street name shall not be abbreviated with the exception of highways. For example, Mount Vernon and Saint Francis shall be used as official street names instead of Mt. Vernon and St. Francis, regardless of how they appear on plats. For geocoding purposes, all punctuation shall be avoided in street names including periods after abbreviations, hyphens and apostrophes. 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-309. - Highway abbreviations. 
    Highway abbreviations shall be inputted as shown below utilizing spaces between words. 
Example Abbreviation Interstate 55 I 55 U.S. Route 30 RT 30 Illinois Route 126 RT 126 Illinois Route 59 RT 59  
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-310. - Geographic directions as part of street names. 
    Geographic directions (north, south, east, west) shall not be used as part of the street name. While these do exist in the Village of Plainfield, such as Northland Street, West Cove Way, Westwind Court, and Eastern Avenue, this practice shall be avoided in future developments. When verbally giving an address such as these, it would be impossible to distinguish between N. Land and Northland for example. 
    Additionally, the adoption of the Chicago Address Grid System in the village allows for only two (2) accepted prefixes: South and west. Therefore, north and east shall not be accepted as directional prefixes in the Village of Plainfield. 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-311. - Street types as part of street names. 
    A street type, like a directional prefix, shall be avoided as part of the root street name. For example, a street named Winding Trail Drive is confusing since Trail and Drive are both street types. Country Walk Lane Court is another example where the street type Court was simply added without deleting the type Lane . 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-312. - Street name continuity. 
    Street name continuity is the retention of one street name for the entire length of the street, including streets aligned parallel in adjacent subdivisions. This is not to be confused with street name duplication in which case streets that are not continuous are given the same name. Street name continuity shall be used when possible. Allowances can be made for gaps in a street's continuity as in cases of undeveloped land. However, if a case arises in which street name continuity has been established in two (2) or more subdivisions with a gap of undeveloped land in between, the gap, when developed shall continue that street and street name in its development to establish continuity. If the street shifts off-line by more than two hundred (200) feet, a new street name shall be assigned. 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-313. - Street name duplication. 
    Street name duplication shall not be allowed in the Village of Plainfield. However, any new development that may be developed between an undeveloped area and an existing subdivision where a planned street aligns with an existing street in the developed subdivision, shall be allowed to continue the name of that existing street in its development plans. However, in this case, the duplicate street must be parallel to the existing street and may not shift off-line by more than two hundred (200) feet in order to retain the existing street name. 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-314. - Development names as street names. 
    Street names shall not reflect the name of a development. Problems arise with implementing continuous street names through other subdivisions when a street name reflects the name of another development. Street names are not marketing tools; their purpose is to enable people to locate addresses readily. 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-315. - Verify spelling. 
    Street naming and spelling shall be consistent when an established street continues through a new subdivision. For example, Governour Street established in one subdivision shall not be spelled as Governor Street as it continues in another Subdivision. 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-316. - Legal and alias street names. 
    Alias street names are other commonly used names for streets. Many streets are known by several different names, such as Pilcher Road is also known as 135th Street, and Lockport Street is also known as Illinois Route 126 and Lockport Road. The name appearing on the recorded subdivision plat map, or street name petition, is usually considered the legal name and used for the situs address. Street names may be changed to a different official name. Any such changes shall be registered in the county recorder of deeds office. Alias street names shall be tracked in the village's master address database for historical and emergency response purposes. 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-317. - Village annexations. 
    For arterial streets annexed by the Village of Plainfield, it is understood the name of the street and the addresses shall conform to the Village of Plainfield's naming conventions. 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Secs. 2.5-318-2.5-330. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - STANDARD FOR STREET NUMBER ASSIGNMENT 

Sec. 2.5-331. - Address numbers. 
    Address numbers shall consist entirely of numbers. This includes street numbers, unit numbers, subunit numbers, and suite numbers. Characters such as hyphens, alpha-characters, and fractions are not acceptable (i.e. 24560 A-1, 24560A and 245601/2). 
    The address number is a unique numerical identifier based on the address grid. The address number shall be five (5) digits in length. The "10000 Blocks" radiate north-south, and the "20000 Blocks" radiate east-west. The numbering system continues to increase southerly and westerly. In the case where a structure is subdivided into more than one external entry occupancies, a unit type and unit number shall be assigned. Suites shall be assigned for all internal occupancies (i.e. business offices, apartments, and condominiums). Subunit numbers and subunit types shall be assigned in those instances where an additional external unit exists within a unit that also contains suites. 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-332. - Address ranges. 
    The possible address range of a street must be identified. It determines which addresses may be given out along the length of the street section. For example, an address number of 23000 shall not be assigned on a block with a potential address range of 22000-22099. In cases where no structures exist on parcels overlapping two (2) blocks, the block with the address range that contains the greater portion of the parcel shall be assigned. In cases where a structure exists on a parcel overlapping two (2) blocks, the block with the address range that contains the greater portion of the structure shall be assigned. In instances where this may cause conflict in address interval assignment, the address range may be left to the discretion of the street address committee for number assignment. 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-333. - Address parity. 
    In the Village of Plainfield, even numbers are located on the north and west sides of the street and odd numbers are located on the south and east sides of the street. This is known as address parity. Addresses across the street from one another shall be comparable. If 22515 is used on the odd-numbered side of a street, numbers close to 22514 or 22516 shall be used on the even side. This is not always possible in practice, particularly on curving streets, but it shall be followed as closely as possible. 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-334. - Numerical sequence. 
    All existing parcels and structures within the Village of Plainfield shall have a valid numerical address. All new parcels and structures within the village shall be provided with an approved numerical address. The village's GIS manager shall approve the use of all proposed numerical addressing within the village after consultation with the street address committee. 
    Assignment of addresses must be done in numerical sequence along a street. Address numbers shall increase as they move either southerly or westerly from the corresponding point on the address grid and they shall not be assigned out of order. For instance, 16441 shall not fall between 16359 and 16410. 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-335. - Address intervals. 
    The GIS manager must consider both current and future development for assigning address numbers. Future growth may make it necessary to insert address numbers between those currently being assigned. Planning shall include a large enough numbering interval to allow for expansion and growth. Even numbered addresses (i.e. 12310, 12314, 12318, etc.) shall be used to identify all lots located on the north and west side of the road. Odd numbered addresses (i.e. 12311, 12315, 12319, etc.) shall be used to identify all lots located on the south and east side of the road. Assignment of address intervals shall be determined upon the number of structures that need to be numbered within each block. Each block shall not exceed sixty-six (66) addresses (thirty-three (33) even and thirty-three (33) odd). 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-336. - Duplicate numbers. 
    No duplicate numbers shall be assigned on a street. This includes addresses on streets that are extensions of a main street (i.e. place, courts and circles). If there is a 12250 S Rock Dr., then there shall not be a 12250 S Rock Ct. 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-337. - Long streets. 
    In subdivision developments having long blocks with no intersecting streets, addresses shall correspond with the appropriate address range for each section of the block. The long streets may be trending or diagonal and shall be numbered in the direction of the greatest distance of which the trend or diagonal covers (north/south or east/west). 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-338. - Corner lots. 
    A structure located at the corner of two (2) intersecting streets shall be addressed from the street from which the front door is positioned. A request for a business to be addressed off of a major street shall not be permitted unless the major street borders that property, and the front door is obscured or invisible from the road, or the structure is obviously best reached for emergency purposes by the driveway. In this instance, the street number shall be assigned based on where the driveway intersects the road. 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-339. - Courts. 
    A court shall have the same name as the street from which it branches (See Figure 1). If the court exceeds the length outlined in the village's subdivision ordinance, it shall be given a unique street name and numbered accordingly (See Figure 2). However, in the case where more than one court branches off the same street, each court shall have a different street name then the street from which it branches. In each of the cases listed above, the street type classification for each of the courts shall be court . On the contrary, if a court is less than the length outlined in the village's subdivision ordinance for a court , it shall retain the street name, street numbering sequence, and street type designation of the main street. In other words, if it is not a true court , the street shall not be labeled as a court (See Figure 3). 
    The numbering pattern for courts shall follow the numbering pattern, interval, and direction from the Village's address grid system and shall not continue from the street from which it branches. Likewise, in the case where there is more than one (1) court off the same street, each court shall follow the address interval relative to its location on the address grid system with no courts duplicating address intervals from the other courts . In other words, in this instance, no court shall be assigned the same address. Courts shall have the even and Figure 1 odd address numbers meet at the closed end of the street. 

Figure 1 
  

Figure 2 
  

Figure 3 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-340. - Circles. 
    A circle is defined as a court that terminates at the end of a street. The name, numbering pattern, interval and direction are continued from the street on which the circle stems. The street type classification Circle may be used to name the entire street, or it may be used to name the court portion of the street only if there is a natural breaking point, such as an intersecting street that may separate and distinguish the two (2) sections (See Figure 4). Circles shall be numbered like any regular street and have the even and odd address numbers meet at the closed end of the street. 

Figure 4 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-341. - Closed loop. 
    If a street forms a closed loop , addressing shall proceed clockwise from the base of the loop of the street from which it branches. Closed loops shall be numbered like any regular street and shall have the even and odd address numbers meet at the closed end of the loop. 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-342. - Crescents. 
    A crescent is defined as a street that intersects at two (2) points from the same collector street. Crescent streets are numbered consecutively starting from one point and terminating at the second point. The street numbers for this street configuration shall not be assigned consecutively from the street from which it extends. Instead, the street numbers shall be assigned according to the direction in which it covers the greatest distance being north/south or east/west. Likewise, odd numbers shall be located on the south and east sides of the street, with even numbers on the north and west sides of the street (See Figure 5). 

Figure 5 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-343. - Streets that change direction. 
    For streets that change direction, the street shall retain its original address grid and range throughout its entire length no matter how many times the roadway turns or bends (See Figure 6). In the instance where the street curve shifts at a 90-degree angle changing the major direction of the street, it may be acceptable to assign a new street name (See Figure 7). However, streets with more than one (1) curve may not follow this exception as it may produce a hidden street. Likewise, this method shall not be used if the second section of street at the 90-degree angle is very short. 

Figure 6 
  

Figure 7 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-344. - Vanity street names. 
    A vanity street is a street named after a company, corporation, individual, etc., usually as a condition of a land dedication. If vanity street names are used, their numbering shall be consistent with the address grid. Acme Company shall not use "Number One Acme Drive" as their address but must be numbered according to the established address range. In addition, vanity street names shall not be allowed for only a segment of a street, but if used must be used for the entire street length (See Figure 8). 

Figure 8 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-345. - Vacant parcels and theoretical addresses. 
    Most jurisdictions do not assign an official address to a vacant land parcel until a building permit has been issued for new construction. Often though, an unofficial address will be pre-assigned as a guide. For example, theoretical addresses are usually assigned to the lots in approved residential subdivisions before new homes are built. For geographic information systems (GIS) referencing purposes an unofficial address shall be assigned to each existing parcel even if the address is theoretical and could change when a building permit is issued. If a large vacant parcel occupies an entire block it would normally be given a theoretical address in the middle of the corresponding thousand block range. For example, a vacant parcel on the even side of the 12000 block would be addressed as 12050 rather than 12000 or 12002. Sometimes a very large parcel, such as in a rural setting, will reside in more than one thousand block range. Like the previous example, the unofficial address shall be about halfway between the ranges. If the parcel occupies two (2) blocks, such as between 17000-19000, it would be given an address of 18000. This will allow for the parcel to be subdivided later and still have sequential address numbers. An unofficial address on a vacant parcel may be altered by any new addresses assigned by a building permit. This would be in cases where the expected pattern of development for a vacant parcel shall require different or additional addresses. General address standards would then apply. However, whenever possible, the unofficial address shall be issued as the official address on the building permit. 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-346. - Single family residential development. 
(a)  All residential subdivision developments shall be assigned one development or project address as approved by the village. This address shall be the same as the existing parcel address maintained in the master address database, or shall be assigned another address if the parcel is to be subdivided. This address shall be used to identify the property until the street address committee approves addresses for each individual lot within the subdivision. After the subdivision has been fully developed, the theoretical address shall no longer be used, but shall be listed as a historical address in the master address database. 
(b)  Sales, construction, and other miscellaneous structures and trailers used during the construction of projects shall use the project address assigned to the development. All temporary structures and trailers shall be assigned a designated unit number approved by the village. Temporary unit numbers shall be numerical in sequence (100, 101, 102, 103 etc....) based upon the order in which the structures are placed on the project site. 
(c)  Each proposed lot within a single family residential development shall be assigned one numerical address. However, no lot shall use the theoretical or existing parcel address. 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-347. - Duplexes and townhomes. 
    Duplexes and townhomes shall be assigned individual street numbers for each residence following the appropriate numbering pattern, interval and direction stipulated for individual lots. In cases where duplexes and townhomes are perpendicular to the street from which it is being addressed from, street numbering shall be left to the discretion of the GIS manager. 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-348. - Stacked addresses. 
    Houses or trailers behind or next to other houses or trailers sharing a common driveway shall be given separate street numbers. Assign the first possible number to the front house and the second number to the next house, etc. If the structures are next to each other, numbering shall continue in sequence. This is much preferred over the use of hyphenated, alphanumeric, or fractional numbering (i.e., 12437-2, 12437B, 124371/2). 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-349. - Commercial development-Single building projects. 
(a)  The theoretical address or development address shall be used for the proposed structure if the proposed structure frontage faces the street used to address the project. If the proposed structure frontage faces in the opposite direction, a new structure address shall be assigned. 
(b)  If the development site is to be subdivided, a new address number shall be assigned for the proposed structure and it shall be consistent with the range of addresses found along the street or road in which they face. In this case, the theoretical address shall not be used, but shall be listed as a historical address in the village's master address database for each of the presubdivided properties. 
(c)  Unoccupied accessory structures such as storage buildings and fire pump buildings shall not be assigned a numerical address. 
(d)  Sales, construction, and other miscellaneous structures and trailers used during the construction of projects shall use the project address assigned to the development. All temporary structures and trailers shall be assigned a designated unit number approved by the village. Temporary unit numbers shall be numerical in sequence (100, 101, 102, 103 etc....) based upon the order in which the structures are placed on the project site. 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-350. - Commercial development-Multi building complexes. 
(a)  One development or project address shall be assigned to the new project by using the address of the parcel the project shall be located on. This address shall be the same as the existing parcel address maintained in the master address database, or shall be assigned another address if the parcel is to be subdivided. This address shall be used to identify the property until the street address committee approves addresses for each individual structure on the development or project site. 
(b)  Commercial projects shall be assigned an individual numerical address for each occupied structure on the site. Address numbers shall be consistent with the range of addresses found along the street or road in which they face. Each structure shall be assigned numbers in sequence by tens (10's) if the address range and number of proposed structures allows for it; otherwise numbers shall be assigned utilizing the best fitting sequence scheme available. Unoccupied accessory structures such as storage buildings and fire pump buildings shall not be assigned a numerical address. 
(c)  When assigning individual structure or lot addresses to the project, the original development address shall not be used for any of the occupied structures or lots. Instead, it shall be listed as an historical address in the master address database. 
(d)  Sales, construction, and other miscellaneous structures and trailers used during the construction of projects shall use the project address assigned to the development. All temporary structures and trailers shall be assigned a designated unit number approved by the village. Temporary unit numbers shall be numerical in sequence (100, 101, 102, 103, etc....) based upon the order in which the structures are placed on the project site. 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-351. - Parks. 
    Parks shall be assigned one numerical address in the proper numerical sequence for the area. 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-352. - Size of street numbers. 
(a)  Size and location. The figures used by owners or occupants of each building to identify the street address of that building shall be plainly visible from the middle of the street, shall not be less than four and a half (4.5) inches high, and shall be located in a conspicuous place immediately over or by the side of the main street entrance to the building, or conspicuously displayed on the mailbox located at and applicable to the property. 
(b)  Color and maintenance. Such numbers shall be of such color as to clearly contrast with the portion of the structure on which the numbers are affixed. The owners or occupants of each building shall maintain all numbers affixed to their respective building. 
(c)  Form. Such numbers shall not be of script form. 
(Ord. No. 2611, § I, 1-8-07; Ord. No. 2722, § 1, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 2.5-353. - Penalties. 
(a)  Failure to number. The owner or occupant of any store, residence or other building now erected, or which may hereafter be erected within the village, who fails to comply with the provisions of this article, shall be fined not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for a first offense, not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) for the second offense, and not less than seventy-five dollars ($75.00) for any subsequent offense. Each day any violation of this section shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  Defacing numbers. Any person who shall willfully deface or remove any number placed upon any building in conformity with this article shall be fined not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. 
(Ord. No. 2611, § I, 1-8-07) 
Secs. 2.5-354-2.5-374. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - STANDARD FOR UNIT, SUBUNIT AND SUITE ASSIGNMENT 

[Sec. 2.5-375. - Standard classifications.] 
    The standard classifications for each type assignment in the master address database shall be defined as listed. 
Type Classification Unit Building, Unit, Parking Lot or Parking Deck Suite Apartment, Suite, Room, Open Subunit Unit, Suite  
(Ord. No. 2722, § 1, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 2.5-376. - Apartments and condominiums. 
(a)  Each apartment or condominium shall have a three-digit suite number posted on the door or next to the door where it is easily visible. The first digit number shall indicate the floor level the apartment or condominium is located on, and the second and third digits are to indicate the individual suite number of the apartment or condominium. For example, the residence located at 12046 W. Main St., Suite 117 shall be located sequentially on the 1st floor of building 12046 on W. Main Street. 
(b)  Each suite space shall be assigned numbers in sequence by a minimum of twos (2's). 
(c)  Apartments and condominiums with suites having interior door entries shall be numbered in position located when facing the front door from the exterior of the building. Suite numbers shall then proceed to be numbered left to right with the lowest suite number on the left and increasing in range to the right. Odd numbers shall be located on one side of the corridor or hallway and even numbers on the opposite side. 
(d)  Apartments or condominiums with exterior door entries shall be assigned a three-digit unit number as outlined in section 2.5-376(a) and (c). 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-377. - Shopping centers and strip malls. 
(a)  Each shopping center and strip mall structure shall be given one primary street address. 
(b)  Each exterior door in a shopping center or strip mall shall be assigned an individual unit number. Businesses that may occupy more than one (1) unit shall clearly display the unit number either on the main entry door or next to the main entry door to the business. The door used as a secondary door for the business shall be assigned a unit number, however, it will be listed as a non-active address in the master address database and shall not be utilized by the current occupant. To avoid confusion, non-active units shall not be labeled on or next to the doorway. In the case where there is a change in occupancy for a unit with a non-active unit number, the unit number shall become active and utilized by the new tenant. 
(c)  Units shall be assigned a three-digit unit number as outlined in section 2.5-376(a). 
(d)  Unit numbers shall be numbered in the order that they are viewed from the front of the structure increasing in range from the left side to the right side of the structure. In those cases where the front entrance of a structure is located on the north or west side of the street it is being addressed from, the units shall be given even unit numbers. In those cases where the front entrance of a structure is located on the south or east side of the street it is being addressed from, the units shall be given odd unit numbers. 
(e)  Unit numbers shall be assigned in sequence by a minimum of twos (2's). 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-378. - Businesses. 
    All multiple tenant structures shall be provided with an approved unit or suite number to identify the individual tenant space. The process for approving proposed unit or suite numbers shall be in accordance with the following criteria: 
(1)  Business structures with tenant spaces having exterior entrances shall be assigned unit numbers and shall follow the unit number assignment process as outlined for shopping centers and strip malls in section 2.5-377(b), (c) and (d) of this ordinance. 
(2)  Business structures with tenant spaces having interior entrances shall be assigned suite numbers and shall follow the suite number assignment process as outlined for apartments and condominiums in section 2.5-376(a) and (c) of this ordinance. 
(3)  Business structures with interior tenants without doorways or closed spaces shall not be addressed with a suite number. This instance commonly occurs in gas stations with donut or coffee shops with businesses located on the interior of the structure. In this case, the suite number type shall be classified as "Open" in the master address database. 
(4)  Each business tenant space (interior or exterior entries) shall be assigned numbers in sequence by a minimum of twos (2's). 
(5)  One-story business structures shall have addresses within the 100 series. Multiple story business structures shall be assigned addresses by floor served (100, 200, 300, 400, etc) and as outlined for apartments and condominiums in section 2.5-376(a). 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-379. - Hotel addressing. 
    The applicant is to provide an addressing plan for all suites including the identification number and location of each room. A copy of the plan shall be submitted to the village GIS manager for approval by the village street address committee. Each room is to have a unique number in accordance with the floor the room shall be located on as described below. 
(1)  Each room with a door on a fire-rated corridor or available to the public is to have a (3) three-digit room number posted at the door. The first digit is to indicate the floor level and the second and third digits are to indicate the individual room on the floor. Rooms shall be numbered in the order that they are accessed from the main entrance with odd numbers on one side of the corridor or hallway and even on the other side. 
(2)  Rooms that are not being utilized as guest rooms shall be clearly labeled as "meeting room", "office", "storage", etc. and shall not be assigned a suite number. 
(3)  Each suite space shall be assigned numbers in sequence by a minimum of twos (2's). 
(4)  Hotels with internal suites shall follow the suite number assignment process as outlined for apartments and condominiums in section 2.5-376(c). 
(5)  Hotels with external suites shall follow the suite number assignment process as outlined for apartments and condominiums in section 2.5-376(d). 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-380. - Campus addressing. 
    A campus shall be defined as those properties containing a large area of grounds with two or more buildings, parking lots and decks, such as for hospitals or medical centers, conference centers, church campuses, sport or recreational facilities, or universities and schools. The applicant shall submit a detailed copy of the campus plan to the village GIS manager showing building, parking lot and parking deck address assignment as well as interior campus streets (public and non-public) layout. For campus addressing, units , subunits and suites shall be utilized, where applicable, to differentiate between structure types. 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Secs. 2.5-381-2.5-400. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - APPURTENANCES AND UTILITY ASSETS NUMBERING FROM PROPERTY ADDRESS 

Sec. 2.5-401. - Appurtenances and utility assets. 
    Addressing for the following list of appurtenances and utility assets in the Village of Plainfield shall be assigned as stated below: 
Cable Panel Vaults 
Electric Meters 
Electric Pedestals 
Electric Panel Vaults 
Electric Power Poles 
Electric Reader Boards 
Hydrants 
Monument Signs 
Stormwater Outfalls 
Telephone Panel Vaults 
Utility Sheds 
Wastewater Services 
Water Backflows 
Water Irrigation Meters 
Water Service 
    Address assignment for the above listed appurtenances/assets shall use the existing valid situs or, if available, secondary situs address of the parcel the appurtenance shall be located on. To assist field staff with locating the appurtenance in the field, all asset information entered into village data systems shall include the valid situs/secondary address and in addition, a brief description of where the appurtenance is located on the parcel. 
    Exceptions to the above exist for the following: 
(1)  Appurtenances located on the property line between parcels. For appurtenances located directly on the property line between parcels, either one of the immediately adjacent parcel addresses may be used if both parcels are addressed off the same frontage street. If the adjacent parcels are addressed off different streets, the parcel address that contains the street the property line fronts shall be used. If several types of appurtenances are to be located on the same property line, all shall use the same address. 
(2)  Appurtenances located near a parcel but not on a parcel. For appurtenances located near a parcel but not directly on the parcel, the situs address of the parcel located closest to the appurtenance shall be used to identify the asset. 
(3)  Appurtenances located in rights-of-way medians. Appurtenances located in street medians shall be addressed by utilizing the address of the parcel located closest to the median, or the parcel address where the power supply pedestal for the appurtenance is located. When identical addresses are used for separate appurtenance locations, a location description shall be included. 
(4)  Traffic signals. Traffic signal addresses are determined by the address of the parcel where the power supply pedestal for the traffic light controller box is located. 
(5)  Appurtenances and utility assets with separate addresses. Addressing for the following list of appurtenances and utility assets in the Village of Plainfield shall be assigned separate addresses: 
Cell Towers 
Water Towers 
Wells 
Lift Stations 
Electric Transformer Switching Stations 
Gas Pipelines 
Gas Vaults 
Gas Stations 
Pipes (Above Ground) 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Secs. 2.5-402-2.5-414. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 9. - STANDARD FOR DIRECTIONAL PREFIXES 

[Sec. 2.5-415. - Standard directional prefix and suffix abbreviations.] 
    The standard directional prefixes are always abbreviated and capitalized, but no punctuation, including periods, shall be used. Standard directional prefix and suffix abbreviations include the following: 
Example Abbreviation North N South S East E West W  
    Although northwest (NW), northeast (NE), southwest (SW), and southeast (SE) are prefixes that may be used in some surrounding municipalities, they shall not used in the Village of Plainfield. 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-416. - Directional prefix. 
    A directional prefix is required as part of the official site address. The use of S and W, shall be the only acceptable directional prefixes used for addresses in the Village of Plainfield. Any previous N or E prefix shall be listed as a previous prefix directional in the master address database. 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-417. - Diagonal or curving streets. 
    Diagonal or curving streets, with one street name, shall be determined to be either a north-south or an east-west street for its entire length, and shall retain the directional prefix throughout the entire length of the street. However, long streets with a 90-degree curve may sometimes be dealt with as two (2) separate streets with different names even if there isn't an actual intersection. In this case, each street section with a unique name may have a different directional prefix. 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Secs. 2.5-418-2.5-424. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 10. - STANDARD FOR STREET TYPE ASSIGNMENT 

Sec. 2.5-425. - Street types. 
    Street types for the village shall include the following listed below. 
Street Type Abbreviation Avenue AVE Boulevard BLVD Circle CIR Court CT Cove CV Crossing XING Drive DR Highway HWY Lane LN Parkway PKWY Place PL Road RD Route RTE Street ST Trail TRL Way WAY  
(Ord. No. 2722, § 1, 12-17-07; Ord. No. 2989, § I, 5-2-11) 
Sec. 2.5-426. - Correct use of street types. 
    All streets shall have a street type. If a street type is not specifically assigned on the official plat map, the default is street. If a platted street uses one of the above street types, it shall be the official type whether it is abbreviated on the plat map or not. For example, if a new street is on the plat map as Moose Trail, then Trail is the official street type. It would not be Moose Trail Street as this would go against the directive that street types shall be avoided as part of the root street name. 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-427. - Root street names. 
    Once a root street name is assigned it must not be used again with a different type except in the case of Court or Circle . For example, the use of both Maple Lane and Maple Trail is not acceptable. However, Maple Lane and Maple Court are acceptable. The street type Place may also be used in this instance only if it extends from the street from which it is using the root street name. 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-428. - Alley. 
    An alley is a short, narrow passage, not commonly used for through traffic, and is generally located behind buildings in between two (2) blocks. No addresses shall be assigned to structures from an alley . 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Secs. 2.5-429-2.5-450. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 11. - STREET NAMING PROCEDURE 

Sec. 2.5-451. - Highway and route numbers. 
    The following street names that also have a given highway name/number or route number shall be addressed with the highway name/number or route number. All other street names for a street shall be recorded as aliases. However, the following are exceptions (*) to this naming procedure: 
(1)  Lincoln Highway/Illinois Route 30 shall be known as Lincoln Highway from the intersection of W Renwick Road and south to Interstate 55. However, Lincoln Highway/Route 30 shall be known as Joliet Road between S Route 59 and the intersection of W Renwick Road. 
(2)  Illinois Route 30 shall be known as S Route 30 between its intersection at W Lockport Street and north to the village's northern political boundary. 
(3)  W Lockport Street shall be recognized as the legal name for Lockport Street extending from the village's eastern political boundary from Interstate 55 to the proposed area designated as its terminus with the future re-routing of Illinois Route 126. 
(4)  With the future re-routing proposed for Illinois Route 126 from the village's western political boundary to 143rd Street the legal name shall be W Route 126 . Main Street shall become the recognized name of Illinois Route 126 between W Lockport Street and Interstate 55. 
(5)  County Route 11/Plainfield Road/Plainfield-Oswego Road/Stewart Road shall be known as Ridge Road from the village's southern political boundary to the village's northern political boundary, and shall be known as Plainfield Road from the point where Plainfield-Oswego Road intersects Ridge Road from its western political boundary.

(a)  East - West Streets:

(b)  North - South Streets: 
Addressing Name Alias(es) S Book Road 232 nd Avenue S Drauden Road Heggs Road, Steiner Road S Essington Road 224 th Avenue S Joliet Road Lincoln Highway, U.S. Route 30 S Naperville Road Naperville/Plainfield Road S Normantown Road 252 nd Avenue S Plainfield Road Plainfield/Oswego Road S Ridge Road County Route 11, Plainfield Road, Plainfield/Oswego Road, and Stewart Road  
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06; Ord. No. 2722, § 1, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 2.5-453. - Naming streets and changing existing street names. 
(a)  An official name shall be given to a private street and approved by the GIS manager when: 
(1)  The private street services five (5) or more residences, or 
(2)  The location and/or length of the private street are such that for safety and emergency purposes, it is more appropriate to name the private street than to assign addresses from the main road. 
(b)  The existing street name, or the name applied to a right-of-way as shown on an approved preliminary plat or recorded plat, shall be changed when: 
(1)  Road construction has resulted in the extension of one (1) street to another street so that both streets are joined in such a manner that both streets shall be considered one street. 
(2)  In the instance of changing a street name, one (1) of the two (2) existing street names shall be used. The GIS manager shall determine which street name is used based on: 
 The street name which results in the fewest number of address changes. 
 The street name which is oldest. 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-454. - Notification of street names. 
    The GIS manager shall notify interested persons whenever a street is named for the first time, and whenever an existing street name is changed: 
(1)  In the case of naming streets or street right-of ways as part of the process of approving final plat, the record in the Will County or Kendall County Recorder of Deeds Office shall be of sufficient notice. 
(2)  In cases of naming streets for the first time, written notice shall contain: 
a.  The new street name. 
b.  A structure's new address and description of the location of the structure. 
c.  The extent of the street the street name is to be applied to. 
(3)  Notices shall be sent to the following interested persons: 
a.  The respective County's Assessor's office. 
b.  The respective County's Planning office. 
c.  The respective County's E911 office. 
d.  The respective village departments. 
e.  The respective Fire District's office. 
f.  U.S. Post Office. 
g.  The respective Park District office. 
h.  Residents, occupants, and owners who will have an address on the street. 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Secs. 2.5-455-2.5-475. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 12. - ADDRESSING PROCEDURE 

Sec. 2.5-476. - Changing address numbers. 
    It shall be the policy of this ordinance to discourage the practice of changing existing addresses or address numbers which are already in use except: 
(1)  If the existing address number is not in sequence and or does not run consecutively in the same direction as the village address system. 
(2)  If the existing number is such that the assignment of address numbers for new structures is not practical and in keeping with the requirements. 
(3)  When a new street is constructed, or recognized, which results in the most appropriate address for a structure to be on the new street rather than the original street such as where a structure is previously on land locked property and for example, then has a new street built to service it. 
(4)  If it is determined that an address needs to be changed for safety and emergency purposes. 
 Number is out of proper sequence. 
 Number series presently in use is incorrect or misleading. 
 Odd or even number on wrong side of roadway. 
 Principal entrance does not face the street as now addressed. 
 New street intersection makes present number outmoded. 
 Change of street designation. 
 Designation of private roadway. 
 Identical numbers on similar street. 
 Not using assigned address. 
 No address presently assigned. 
 Change from rural route and box number to urban type address. 
 Present address is misleading. 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Sec. 2.5-477. - Master address database. 
    The GIS manager shall keep a master file of maps showing the location of each parcel and structure which have an address and the address number. The master file shall be automatically updated as addresses are assigned. Two (2) lists shall be derived from the master file: 
(1)  A master index of the proper names of each street in the Village of Plainfield shall be kept. 
(2)  A list of address numbers shall be compiled which contains all the former addresses and the respective new addresses along with the name of the residents, occupants, persons, and owners who were required to receive notice. This list shall be updated as addresses are assigned. The list shall be sent to: 
a.  Will or Kendall County Emergency Services. 
b.  Will or Kendall County Sheriff's Department. 
c.  Plainfield or Oswego Fire District. 
d.  Kendall County GIS Department. 
(Ord. No. 2598, § II(Exh. A), 12-6-06) 
Secs. 2.5-478-2.5-500. - Reserved.

Appendix A: Village of Plainfield Address Grid

Sec. 2.5-501. - Permit fees. 
    The fee for permits issued for all building or construction within the corporate limits of the village shall be the fees and charges as set forth herein: 
(a)  All single-family and multifamily residential structures, including all basements, and attached garages (fees are not required for crawl space areas) : 
A gross area fee of nine cents ($0.09) per cubic foot. 
(b)  All other nonresidential buildings including, but not limited to, all commercial, industrial and office buildings : 
1.  First 100,000 cubic feet, per cubic foot ..... $0.04 
100,001 up to and including 200,000 cubic feet, per cubic foot ..... 0.02 
200,001 up to and including 500,000 cubic feet, per cubic foot ..... 0.01 
500,001 and in excess, per cubic foot ..... 0.006 
2.  All additions to previously existing industrial buildings: A building permit fee of four-tenths of one cent ($0.004) per cubic foot. 
3.  A fee of fifty (50) percent of the customary cubic content fee shall apply for alterations, conversions, remodeling, and structural repairs for all nonresidential uses. The minimum fee is two hundred dollars ($200.00).

(f)  All gazebo and pergolas. A building permit fee fifty dollars ($50.00) plus electric inspection fee, if applicable. 
(g)  All alterations, conversions, remodeling, structural repairs, interior remodeling and fire remodels. A set building permit fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) plus electric and plumbing inspection fees if applicable for all residential uses. 
(h)  Other alterations. The following fees shall apply to all other alterations to property or structures, including but not limited to, tool sheds, garden houses, porches, dormers, and fences: Forty dollars ($40.00) plus electric and plumbing inspection fees, if applicable. 
(i)  [Electrical and plumbing inspections.] Electrical and plumbing inspections shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each residential inspection and all nonresidential inspections shall be thirty dollars ($30.00) per inspection. 
(j)  Swimming pools. 
Above ground ..... $55.00 
Below ground ..... 150.00

(l)  All lawn irrigation. A building permit fee forty-five dollars ($45.00).

(Ord. No. 3249, § 1(Exh. A), 1-4-16) 
Sec. 2.5-502. - Re-inspection fee. 
    A fee of sixty dollars ($60.00) for re-inspection at rough framing and final occupancy stages. A re-inspection fee of forty dollars ($40.00) for all other inspections. Plumbing and electric fees are based per inspection. 
(Ord. No. 3249, § 1(Exh. A), 1-4-16) 
Sec. 2.5-503. - Plan review deposit. 
    A minimum plan review deposit for new construction and additions shall be required. Permits for alterations, conversions, remodeling, structural repairs, interior remodeling, fences, sheds, decks, breezeways, screen porches and gazebos shall not be required to provide a plan review deposit. The following nonrefundable deposit, which will be credited to the final building permit fee, but which will in all cases be the minimum fee, shall be paid at the time plans for the following types of construction are submitted for review: 
(a)  Residential : 
Detached residential dwellings, per unit ..... $200.00 
Attached residential dwellings, per unit ..... 100.00 
Residential addition, per unit (in no event shall the plan review deposit exceed the cost of the permit) ..... 50.00 
(b)  Commercial, industrial, institutional and miscellaneous : 
First 4,000 square feet (minimum fee) ..... $200.00 
In the event an outside consultant is employed by the village for plan review services, the fee will equal the village's actual cost for services. 
(c)  Preliminary plan review (pre-application) . Payment of the appropriate deposit shall be paid in advance of staff review. The permit application shall be credited to the prepaid deposit when an application is made. 
(d)  Responsibility for costs . The applicant shall be responsible for the actual costs incurred by the village in cases where consultants are used to conduct building permit related construction plan reviews. The village reserves the right to hire a qualified consultant to perform plan review services for any building permit application. The applicant shall be informed of the reason for such decision and the estimated costs associated with the consultant services prior to conducting the plan review. 
(Ord. No. 3249, § 1(Exh. A), 1-4-16) 
Sec. 2.5-504. - Foundation permit fee. 
    Foundation permits requested in advance of full permit issuance shall require the following fees: 
(a)  One- and two-family residential ..... $200.00 
(b)  Multifamily residential, commercial and industrial, per square foot ..... 0.02 
Minimum fee ..... 200.00 
Maximum fee ..... 500.00 
    Foundation permit fees shall be paid in addition to all other fees required for full building permit issuance. 
(Ord. No. 3249, § 1(Exh. A), 1-4-16)

ARTICLE IV. - WATER CONSERVATION 

Sec. 2.6-51. - Restricted hours and days for specified uses; exceptions. 
    Except as provided in subsection 2.6-52(2) below, water from the village water distribution system may only be used for watering or sprinkling of gardens, lawns, shrubs or other outdoor plants, or for filling swimming pools, as follows: 
(1)  All properties with even-numbered street numbers (i.e., numbers ending in 0, 2, 4, 6, or 8) may use village distributed water for plant watering or pool filling on even-numbered calendar dated between the hours of 6:00 a.m. to 10:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. to 10:00 p.m., prevailing time. 
(2)  All properties with odd-numbered street numbers (i.e., street numbers ending in 1, 3, 5, 7 or 9) may use village distributed water for plant watering or pool filling on odd-numbered calendar dates between the hours of 6:00 a.m. to 10:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. to 10:00 p.m., prevailing time. 
(Ord. No. 1844, § I, 4-19-99) 
Sec. 2.6-52. - Special regulations. 
    Notwithstanding the provisions of section 2.6-51 above, the following special regulations shall apply: 
(1)  There shall be no restrictions as to hours or days when water from the village water distribution system may be used for: 
a.  Watering, sprinkling of gardens, trees, shrubs, or other outdoor plants where such watering or sprinkling is done by a person using a hand-held watering device; 
b.  Filling swimming pools with a volume of fifty (50) gallons or less; or 
c.  The automatic watering of trees and shrubs by means of root feeder within the drip line of the tree or shrub. 
For the purpose of this article the "drip line" of a tree or shrub is defined as the ground area immediately beneath the branches of the tree or shrub. The restrictions set forth above shall not apply as to any other lawful use of water from the village water distribution system such as bathing, washing, etc. 
(2)  During the first ten (10) days after new sod or seed has been placed, property owners may use water from the village water distribution system for watering or sprinkling of the sod or seed as follows: 
a.  On the first day that sod or seed is placed the property owners may water the sod or seed for any eight (8) hours. 
b.  For the next nine (9) days after the sod or seed has been placed, the property owner may water the sod or seed every day between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 10:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. and 10:00 p.m., prevailing time. 
c.  Following the first ten (10) days after the sod or seed is placed, the provisions of section 2.6-51 above, shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 1844, § I, 4-19-99) 
Sec. 2.6-53. - Emergency proclamation. 
    Whenever the water supply of the village is diminished, from any cause whatever, to an amount which in the opinion of the village administrator is or is likely to become dangerous to the health and safety of the public, the village administration is hereby authorized and empowered to issue a proclamation in the form of a public notice containing regulations on the use of water from the village water distribution system. Such regulations may provide for limited usage of water, limitations on days and hours of use for some of all purposes, and the prohibition of specified uses. Upon issuing said proclamation, the village administration shall make the contents thereof known to the public by news release to the local newspapers and radio media, and may also notify the citizens in any other practical manner that he shall devise. Further, the village administrator shall immediately notify the mayor and village board members of the nature of the emergency and the regulations that have been imposed. The emergency proclamation of the village administrator and the regulations imposed thereby shall remain in full force and effect until any one of the following shall occur: 
(1)  The village administrator determines that the emergency no longer exists and that the emergency proclamation and the regulations imposed thereby shall no longer continue in effect. 
(2)  The village board modifies, repeals or makes permanent the emergency proclamation and the regulations imposed thereby, by means of an ordinance passed at any regular or special meeting of the board. 
(3)  The first regular meeting of the village board occurring more than thirty (30) days after the emergency proclamation of the village administrator. 
    Any village employee or officer may, at the directions of the village administrator, notify and warn any person of the effect of said proclamation and direct said person to comply with said watering or sprinkling restrictions. If any said person, after having first been warned about said restrictions and said proclamation, shall continue to violate said restrictions and said proclamation, such person shall be deemed to be in violation of this section. 
(Ord. No. 1844, § I, 4-19-99) 
Sec. 2.6-54. - Tampering. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person not authorized by the village to tamper with, alter or damage any part of the village waterworks or supply system, or any meter. 
(Ord. No. 1844, § I, 4-19-99) 
Sec. 2.6-55. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provision of this article, where no other penalty is provided, shall be fined not less than five dollars ($5.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 1844, § I, 4-19-99)

ARTICLE II. - FOOD 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 3-21. - Home kitchen and cottage food operations. 
(a)  The Village of Plainfield hereby adopts and incorporates the provisions of the Food Handling Regulation Enforcement Act (410 ILCS 625/1 et seq.), as amended. 
(b)  Home kitchen operations and cottage food operations, as defined by Food Handling Regulation Enforcement Act, as amended, are permitted within the Village of Plainfield. The sale of non-potentially hazardous food by home kitchen operations and by cottage food operations is also permitted in accordance with the Food Handling Regulation Enforcement Act. 
(c)  The Village of Plainfield hereby authorizes the direct sale of baked goods as described in Section 4 of the Food Handling Regulation Enforcement Act. 
(Ord. No. 3224, § 1, 8-3-15)
