ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 8-1. - Combined waterworks and sewerage system. 
    The waterworks and sewerage systems of the village shall be owned and operated by the village as a combined utility, known as the combined waterworks and sewerage system of the village. 
(Ord. No. 369, 7-12-38; Code 1973, Ch. 6, § 2-4-4) 
Sec. 8-2. - Extension of sewerage and water mains to improved property. 
    All persons who improve property within the village limits shall extend, at their expense, sewerage and water mains of the village to the nearest edge of their property if the nearest edge of their property is within a reasonable distance of the then existing sewerage and water mains. 
(Ord. No. 995, § 2-16-1, 9-15-80) 
Sec. 8-3. - Use of village sewerage and water mains; duties of property owners. 
    All persons tapping onto or otherwise making use of the existing or extended sewerage or water mains of the village, or both, shall extend and maintain, at their own expense, sewerage or water mains, or both, across the complete frontage of their respective property. All water lines and laterals extended from the buffalo box to the respective property shall be installed and maintained by the respective property owner. All sewer lines and laterals extended from the sewer main line to the respective property shall be installed and maintained at the sole expense of the respective property owner. 
(Ord. No. 995, § 2-16-22, 9-15-80) 
Sec. 8-4. - Control of board of trustees over sewerage and water extensions. 
    All engineering, bidding, installation and inspection of extensions to the sewerage and water system of the village shall be at the direction of and under the rules of the board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 995, § 2-16-3, 9-15-80) 
Sec. 8-5. - Costs for utility extensions. 
    Costs of the extension to the sewerage and waterworks systems shall be in addition to other expenses and charges pertaining thereto. 
(Ord. No. 995, § 2-16-4, 9-15-80) 
Sec. 8-6. - Restrictions on water usage. 
(a)  Generally. The use of water shall be limited or not permitted for nonhealth essential purposes when it has been determined by the village president and board of trustees that an adequate supply of water or water pressure is not available for drinking and health related purposes, fire protection and other emergency uses. 
(b)  Notice of restriction. Notice of such water use or restriction shall be disseminated through reasonable communication media throughout the village including, but not limited to, posting notice of the same on the front door of the village municipal building. 
(c)  Enforcement; violation; discontinuance of service; reconnection fee. The superintendent of water and sewer shall have the authority to enforce the provisions of this section by discontinuation of water service in the event of a second violation of this section within a thirty-day period and there shall be a reconnection fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) in the event of discontinuation of service. 
(Ord. No. 1136, § 9-6, 10-19-87; Ord. No. 1169, §§ 1-3, 8-1-88) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 1136, adopted Oct. 19, 1987, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion of the substantive provisions thereof as § 8-6 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference- Sprinkling water on lawns, § 8-52. 
Sec. 8-7. - Adopting electrical aggregation plan of governance. 
    The Will Electric Aggregation Group Plan of Operation and Governance, attached hereto as "Exhibit A" and incorporated by reference herein, is hereby adopted. 
(Ord. No. 3056, § 2, 5-7-12) 
Editor's note- Ord. No 3056, § 2, adopted May 7, 2012, did not specify manner of inclusion; hence, codification as § 8-7 was at the discretion of the editor. Exhibit A is not set out, but may be found at the offices of the village. 
Sec. 8-8. - Authorizing aggregation of electrical load. 
(a)  The Corporate Authorities of the Village of Plainfield find and determine that it is in the best interests of the Village of Plainfield to operate the electric aggregation program under the Act [Illinois Power Agency Act] as an opt-out program. 
(b)  (1)  The Corporate Authorities of the Village of Plainfield hereby are authorized to aggregate in accordance with the terms of the Act residential and small commercial retail electrical loads located within the corporate limits of the Village of Plainfield and for that purpose may solicit bids and enter into service agreements to facilitate for those loads that sale and purchase of electricity and related services and equipment. 
(2)  The Corporate Authorities of the Village of Plainfield are granted the authority to exercise such authority jointly with any other municipality or county and in combination with two or more municipalities or counties, may initiate a process jointly to authorize aggregation by majority vote of each particular municipality or county as required by the Act. 
(3)  The aggregation program for the village shall operate as an opt-out program for residential and small commercial retail customers. 
(4)  The aggregation program shall be approved by a majority of the members of the Corporate Authority of the Village of Plainfield. 
(5)  The corporate authorities of the village with the assistance of the Illinois Power Agency shall develop a plan of operation and governance for the aggregation program and shall conduct such public hearings and provide such public notice as required under the Act. The load aggregation plan shall provide for universal access to all applicable residential customers and equitable treatment of applicable residential customers, shall describe demand management and energy efficiency services to be provided to each class of customers and shall meet any requirements established by law concerning aggregated service offered pursuant to the Act. 
(6)  As an opt-out program, the residential and small commercial retail customers shall be fully informed in advance that they have the right to opt-out of the aggregation program. The disclosure and information provided to the customers shall comply with the requirements of the Act. 
(7)  The electrical aggregation shall occur automatically for each person owning, occupying, controlling or using an electrical load center proposed to be aggregated in the corporate limits of the village, subject to a right to opt-out of the program as described under this section and Act. 
(8)  Because of the way the bidding process works, the village administrator or his designee will need to have the authority to sign a contract with the lowest cost electricity provider on the same day that bids are received. The village Administrator or his designee has the authority to execute a contract with the lowest cost electricity supplier upon receipt and review of the bids. 
(Ord. No. 3057, §§ 2, 3, 5-21-12) 
Editor's note- Ord. No 3057, §§ 2, 3, adopted May 21, 2012, did not specify manner of inclusion; hence, codification as § 8-8 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 8-9-8-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SUPERINTENDENT OF WATER AND SEWER DEPARTMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2. 

Sec. 8-26. - Office created; term. 
    There is hereby created the office of superintendent of the water and sewer department. The superintendent shall hold his office at the will of the president and board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 453, 12-3-45; Code 1973, Ch. 6, § 1-1) 
Sec. 8-27. - Appointment. 
    The superintendent of the water and sewer department shall be appointed by the president of the board of trustees and such appointment shall be made at the first regular meeting of the board after a general municipal election at which a president of the board of trustees is elected, or as soon thereafter as may be deemed practical. 
(Ord. No. 453, 12-3-45; Code 1973, Ch. 6, § 1-2) 
Sec. 8-28. - Duties. 
(a)  The superintendent of the water and sewer department shall have the charge, management and control of the combined water and sewer department and all property pertaining thereto, and it shall be his duty to protect the same from unnecessary damage and to keep the waterworks and sewer system of the village in running order and repair. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the superintendent of the water and sewer department to see that all accounts due the village for water and/or sewer service shall be promptly collected. The superintendent shall conduct such department in accordance with such rules and orders as shall be from time to time given him by the president of the board of trustees. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of the superintendent of the water and sewer department to read the meter of each consumer of water in the village between the twentieth and twenty-fifth days of January, April, July and October of each year, to compute the amount of water used in cubic feet, and to furnish a list of the users of water and/or sewer service, together with the amount of water used by each, to the village treasurer on or before the twenty-ninth day of January, April, July and October of each year. 
(Ord. No. 453, 12-3-45; Code 1973, Ch. 6, § 1-3) 
Sec. 8-29. - Duties of village treasurer. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the village treasurer to compute the amount due the village from each user of water and/or sewer service and to prepare and mail, to each user of such service on or before the first day of February, May, August and November, a statement showing the amount due for services rendered during the previous quarter separately from the amount due, if any, for services rendered prior to such quarter. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the village treasurer to receive all moneys due the village for water and/or sewer service. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of the village treasurer to prepare and deliver to the superintendent of the water and sewer department, at the office of the village treasurer in the village, on the first day of March, June, September and December in each year, and not later than 3:00 p. m. on such days, a list of all delinquent accounts for water and/or sewer service. Such list shall show the amount due for services rendered during the preceding quarter separate from the amount due, if any, for services rendered prior to that time. 
(Ord. No. 453, 12-3-45, Code 1973, Ch. 6, § 1-4) 
Cross reference- Village treasurer, § 2-81 et seq. 
Sec. 8-30. - Mailing notices of delinquent accounts. 
    It shall be the duty of the superintendent of the water and sewer department to mail a notice to each user whose account is delinquent, notifying him that unless such delinquent account is paid within five (5) days from the date thereof, the water service will be discontinued. Such notice shall be mailed on the first day of March, June, September and December. 
(Ord. No. 453, 12-3-45; Code 1973, Ch. 6, § 1-5) 
Sec. 8-31. - Discontinuance of water service until payment of account. 
(a)  If a delinquent bill under this article is not paid within five (5) days after a notice of delinquency is mailed, it shall be the duty of the superintendent of the water and sewer department to shut off or discontinue the water service of each user whose account is delinquent. 
(b)  The superintendent of the water and sewer department shall not be required to furnish water service again to such consumer until the delinquent account of such consumer is paid in full, unless he is so ordered by the president and board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 453, 12-3-45; Code 1973, Ch. 6, § 1-5) 
Sec. 8-32. - Books and accounts kept by superintendent. 
    The superintendent of the water and sewer department shall keep such books and accounts as the president of the board of trustees shall from time to time designate or prescribe. 
(Ord. No. 453, 12-3-45; Code 1973, Ch. 6, § 1-6) 
Sec. 8-33. - Reports. 
    The superintendent of the water and sewer department shall make reports to the board as may from time to time be requested by it. 
(Ord. No. 453, 12-3-45; Code 1973, Ch. 6, § 1-7) 
Sec. 8-34. - Defective meters. 
    It shall be the duty of the superintendent of the water and sewer department to see that the water meter of each user of the village water service is in working order. If the meter of any such user becomes broken or defective to such an extent that it will not properly measure the water used by such user, it shall be the duty of the superintendent of the water and sewer department to notify such user in writing immediately that his water meter is defective and that unless such meter is repaired or a new meter is installed within ten (10) days, the water service to such consumer shall be discontinued. Unless such meter is repaired or a new meter is installed within time specified in such notice, the superintendent shall shut off and discontinue the water service of such user until same is done. At the user's request, the superintendent is authorized to repair such defective meter and charge the consumer for the cost of the new parts, if any, replaced in such meter and a reasonable amount for repairing same. The superintendent shall furnish such user a temporary meter during the time that the meter of such user is being repaired. At the user's request the superintendent is authorized to install a new meter for such consumer and charge such consumer for the cost of such meter, plus a reasonable charge for the labor required to install same. All amounts due the village for such repairs and for installing such new meters shall be collected by the superintendent and immediately turned over to the village treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 453, 12-3-45; Code 1973, Ch. 6, § 1-8) 
Secs. 8-35-8-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CHARGES, RATES, METERS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 8-46. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the contest clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Act means the Federal Water Pollution Control Act of 1972, as amended, and regulations implementing such Act. 
    B.O.D. (biochemical oxygen demand) means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedures in five (5) days at twenty (20) degrees Celsius, expressed as mg/l. 
    Commercial user means a building discharging domestic wastes only and not classified as either an industrial or a residential user. 
    Customer includes but is not limited to the owner or occupant of the premises served and the user of the services supplied by the combined waterworks and sewerage system of the village having a water meter or a sewer connection or both. 
    Industrial user means any nongovernmental user of publicly owned treatment works identified in the Standard Industrial Classification Manual, 1972, federal office of management and budget, as amended and supplemented, under the following divisions: 
(1)  Division A, agriculture, forestry and fishing; 
(2)  Division B, mining; 
(3)  Division D, manufacturing; 
(4)  Division E, transportation, communications, electric, gas, and sanitary services; 
(5)  Division G, retail trade; 
(6)  Division I, services. 
A user in the divisions listed above may be excluded if it is determined by the superintendent or the federal director that such user will introduce primarily segregated domestic wastes or wastes from sanitary conveniences and is not a major contributing industry as defined in this section. 
    Major contributing industry means an industrial user of the publicly owned treatment works that: (1) Has a flow of fifty thousand (50,000) gallons or more per average workday, or (2) or has a flow greater than five (5) percent of the flow carried by the municipal system receiving the waste, or (3) has in its waste a toxic pollutant in toxic amounts as defined in standards issued under section 307(a) of the Act, or (4) is found by the permit issuance authority, in connection with the issuance of an N.P.D.E.S. permit to the publicly owned treatment works receiving the waste to have a significant impact either singly or in combination with other contributing industries on that treatment works or upon the quality of effluent from that treatment works. 
    Milligrams per liter (mg/l) means a unit of the concentration of water or wastewater constituent. It is one-thousandths of a gram (g) of the constituent in one thousand (1,000) milliliters (ml) of water. It has replaced the unit formerly used commonly (parts per million ppm), to which it is approximately equivalent in reporting the results of water and wastewater analysis. 
    N.P.D.E.S. permit means any permit or equivalent document or requirements issued by the federal administrator, or, where appropriate by the federal director, after enactment of the federal water pollution control amendments of 1972, to regulate the discharge of pollutants pursuant to section 402 of the Act, on file in the office of the village clerk. 
    Population equivalent is a term used to evaluate the impact of industrial or other waste on a treatment works or stream. One (1) population equivalent of normal domestic sewage is one hundred (100) gallons of sewage per day, or seventeen one-hundredths (0.17) pounds of B.O.D. or twenty one-hundredths (0.20) pounds of suspended solids. The impact on a treatment works is evaluated as the equivalent of the highest of the three (3) parameters. The impact on a stream is the higher of the B.O.D. and suspended solids parameters. 
    Residential user means residences, including multiple dwellings, motels, hotels and trailers. 
    User charge means a charge levied on users of the treatment works and/or the waterworks for the cost of operation, maintenance, depreciation charges and all charges necessary to amortize the outstanding water and sewer revenue bonds. 
(Ord. No. 901, § 3-1-1, 12-19-77) 
Sec. 8-47. - Violations. 
    Any person who violates any provision of this article may be deprived of village water or sewer service until such offense is remedied. 
(Ord. No. 901, § 3-2, 12-19-77) 
Sec. 8-48. - Fees due quarterly. 
    Rates or charges under this article shall be payable at least on a quarterly basis. All bills for service rendered shall be payable not later than fifteen (15) days after issuance of same. The customer, the owner of the premises, the occupant thereof and the user of the service shall be jointly and severally liable to pay for the service on such premises, and the service furnished to the premises by the village only upon the condition that said customer, owner, occupant and user are jointly and severally liable therefor to the village. 
(Ord. No. 901, § 3-1-2, 12-19-77; Ord. No. 1395, § 3, 4-6-92) 
Sec. 8-49. - Unpaid fees; liens. 
    For any charges under this article unpaid after thirty (30) days after the date of the original bill, there shall be added and become due a penalty of ten (10) percent of the amount of the original bill, and in addition thereto the sum of one (1) percent per month shall accrue on all outstanding charges. As additional penalties, costs of preparation or filing of statements of delinquencies, as set forth herein, shall attach to the account of the delinquent customer. 
(Ord. No. 1021, § 3-1-3, 6-15-81) 
Sec. 8-50. - Discontinuance of service. 
    If the rates or charges for the service are not paid within thirty (30) days after rendition of the bill for such services, such service shall be discontinued without further notice. 
(Ord. No. 901, § 3-1-4, 12-19-77) 
Sec. 8-51. - Rates; charges. 
    There are hereby established rates or charges for the use of and service supplied by the combined waterworks and sewerage system of the village, as follows: 
(1)  For water usage as indicated by the water meter: 
a.  A minimum charge of six dollars and seventy-nine cents ($6.79) per month for the first one hundred (100) cubic feet of water or part thereof furnished during the month, effective February 1, 2018. A minimum charge of seven dollars and nine cents ($7.09) per month for the first one hundred (100) cubic feet of water or part thereof furnished during the month, effective February 1, 2019. A minimum charge of seven dollars and thirty-nine cents ($7.39) per month for the first one hundred (100) cubic feet of water or part thereof furnished during the month, effective February 1, 2020. A minimum charge of seven dollars and sixty-nine cents ($7.69) per month for the first one hundred (100) cubic feet of water or part thereof furnished during the month, effective February 1, 2021. 
b.  A rate of six dollars and seventy-nine cents ($6.79) per additional one hundred (100) cubic feet of water or part thereof in excess of one hundred (100) cubic feet of water or part thereof furnished during the month, effective February 1, 2018. A rate of seven dollars and nine cents ($7.09) for each additional one hundred (100) cubic feet of water or part thereof in excess of one hundred (100) cubic feet of water or part thereof furnished during the month, effective February 1, 2019. A rate of seven dollars and thirty-nine cents ($7.39) for each additional one hundred (100) cubic feet of water or part thereof in excess of one hundred (100) cubic feet of water or part thereof furnished during the month, effective February 1, 2020. A rate of seven dollars and sixty-nine cents ($7.69) for each additional one hundred (100) cubic feet of water or part thereof in excess of one hundred (100) cubic feet of water or part thereof furnished during the month, effective February 1, 2021. 
c.  For water service furnished to customers outside the corporate limits of the village, the rate shall be two (2) times the aforesaid rates in subsection (1) for water furnished to customers inside the corporate limits of the village. 
(2)  For sewer service furnished to customers within the corporate limits of the village: 
a.  Basic user rate: There shall be and there is hereby established a minimum charge and basic user rate for the use of and for services supplied by the waste water facilities of the Village of Plainfield. A minimum charge of nine dollars and eighty-one cents ($9.81) per month shall be applied to all users inside the corporate limits of the Village of Plainfield whose water consumption does not exceed three hundred (300) cubic feet per month, effective February 1, 2018. Said minimum charge shall be ten dollars and sixty-two cents ($10.62) effective February 1, 2019; eleven dollars and forty-three cents ($11.43) effective February 1, 2020; and twelve dollars and twenty-four cents ($12.24) effective February 1, 2021. 
b.  A rate of three dollars and twenty-seven cents ($3.27) per additional one hundred (100) cubic feet of water or part thereof in excess of three hundred (300) cubic feet of water or part thereof furnished during the month, effective February 1, 2018. A rate of three dollars and fifty-four cents ($3.54) for each additional one hundred (100) cubic feet of water or part thereof in excess of three hundred (300) cubic feet of water or part thereof furnished during the month, effective February 1, 2019. A rate of three dollars and eighty-one cents ($3.81) for each additional one hundred (100) cubic feet of water or part thereof in excess of three hundred (300) cubic feet of water or part thereof furnished during the month, effective February 1, 2020. A rate of four dollars and eight cents ($4.08) for each additional one hundred (100) cubic feet of water or part thereof in excess of three hundred (300) cubic feet of water or part thereof furnished during the month, effective February 1, 2021. 
c.  Reserved. 
d.  The industrial and commercial user charge shall be based upon metered water usage during each quarter. The village or user may elect, at the user's expense, to install a sampling and flow measurement facility and compute all charges based upon quality and quantity of flow. In the event that meter(s) associated with the user's manufacturing processes are used in calculating water usage and/or sewerage usage, the user shall grant access to such facility and meter or meters at a time reasonable to the village or its agents and shall bear the cost of ascertaining the validity and accuracy of such meters upon demand by the village. 
e.  Major contributing industrial users, if required by the village, shall install, operate and maintain a flow measurement and sampling facility to meet village requirements and shall pay all sewer charges based upon quality and quantity of flow from this facility. Access to such facility shall be guaranteed the village at all times for monitoring or checking purposes. 
f.  In addition to those charges based upon quantity of flow, all commercial and industrial users shall pay a surcharge based upon quality of effluent discharged to the village sewer system as follows: 
B.O.D., nineteen cents ($0.19) per pound for that which exceeds two hundred (200) mg/l on a daily average; 
Suspended solids, seventeen cents ($0.17) for that which exceeds two hundred fifty (250) mg/l on a daily average; 
Fats, grease and oil (hexane) solubles or equivalents, fifty cents ($0.50) per mg/l per one thousand (1,000) gallons for that which exceeds one hundred (100) mg/l. 
g.  For sewer service furnished outside the corporate limits of the village, all of the above charges in paragraph (2) shall be two (2) times the aforesaid rates for sewer service furnished to customers inside the corporate limits of the village. 
h.  The village shall maintain a program of monitoring industrial and commercial effluent as it deems necessary, except that major industries shall be monitored not less than four (4) times annually and any commercial or industrial establishments with a population equivalent of one hundred (100) or more shall be monitored at least once annually. Monitoring shall consist of taking and testing "grab" or composite samples as deemed necessary by the village. If no access to the user's service line is available, the village may require the user to install a control manhole in its service line. 
(3)  The capital improvement charge shall be reduced from seven dollars ($7.00) per month to six dollars and fifty cents ($6.50) per month, per account, effective February 1, 2018. 
    The village will offer a ten-percent discount, to be applied to the total monthly water and sanitary sewer charges, for senior citizens that qualify for the "Senior Citizens Assessment Freeze Exemption" as defined by the county treasurer. This discount will apply to only one (1) residential account for a qualifying senior citizen. 
(Ord. No. 901, § 3-1-5, 12-19-77; Ord. No. 1104, § 3-1-5, 3-17-86; Ord. No. 1217, §§ 1, 2, 4-3-89; Ord. No. 1395, §§ 1, 2, 4-6-92; Ord. No. 1612, §§ 1, 2, 4-17-95; Ord. No. 1720, §§ 1, 2, 12-16-96; Ord. No. 1790, § 2, 4-20-98; Ord. No. 1966, §§ 1, 2, 4-17-2000; Ord. No. 2120, § 1, 4-15-02; Ord. No. 2224, § 1, 4-21-03; Ord. No. 2396, § 1, 4-5-04; Ord. No. 2852, § I, 4-6-09; Ord. No. 2927, §§ I, II, 3-15-10, eff. 5-1-10; Ord. No. 2987, §§ I-III, 4-18-11; Ord. No. 3031, §§ I-III, 12-19-11; Ord. No. 3135, § 1, 12-16-13; Ord. No. 3194, § 1, 12-15-14; Ord. No. 3290, § 1, 12-19-16; Ord. No. 3344, 1-8-18) 
Sec. 8-52. - Sprinkling of water on lawns. 
    For due cause, the village president may prohibit the sprinkling of water on lawns, and upon publication of such prohibition, it shall be unlawful for a customer of the village system to sprinkle water on lawns. 
(Ord. No. 901, § 3-1-6, 12-19-77) 
Cross reference- Restrictions on water usage, § 8-6. 
Sec. 8-53. - Revenues deposited with treasurer. 
    All the revenues and monies derived from the operation of the combined waterworks and sewerage system shall be held by the collector separate and apart from all other funds of the village, and all of such sum, without any deduction whatever, shall be delivered to the village treasurer not more than ten (10) days after receipt of the same, or at such more frequent intervals as may from time to time be directed by the board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 901, § 3-1-8, 12-19-77) 
Cross reference- Village treasurer, § 2-81 et seq. 
Sec. 8-54. - Duties of treasurer. 
    The village treasurer shall establish a proper system of accounts and shall keep proper books, records and accounts in which complete and correct entries shall be made of all transactions relative to the combined waterworks and sewerage system; shall receive all such revenues from the sewerage system and all other funds and monies incident to the operation of such system as the same may be delivered to him; and shall deposit the same in a separate fund designated as the "waterworks and sewerage fund" of the village. The treasurer shall administer such funds in every respect in the manner provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 901, § 3-1-9, 12-19-77) 
Sec. 8-55. - Temporary service. 
    Temporary service may be furnished contractors or builders for water to be used on construction work, upon terms agreed on by the village board. 
(Ord. No. 901, § 3-1-10, 12-19-77) 
Sec. 8-56. - Privilege of water and sewer connection; charges. 
(a)  Before or at the time of issuing any building permit involving any water connection to the water main or sewer connection to the sewer main which is a part of the combined sewer and waterworks of the village for the purpose of obtaining water service or sewer service for any property abutting such water or sewer main, the owner or owners of such property or the contractor desiring to make such connection shall make application, in writing, to the village clerk for a permit to connect such water line or sewer line and, in addition to all other charges established by ordinance, pay to the village clerk the following fee or fees for each connection, which fee or fees shall be considered the basic water and sewer connection charges for all users: 
(1)  Water connection fees.

The population equivalent stated on the IEPA permit shall be the basis for calculating the required connection fees. However, said basis shall be subject to review with individual building permit applicants. 
    The village may require the owner or owners to execute in writing an application and affidavit acknowledging and agreeing to initiate substantial construction in installing improvements within ninety (90) days of receiving any IEPA sewer construction permits. If substantial improvements are not initiated within said ninety (90 days, the village shall be authorized to request that said permit be declared null and void and the village will return any fees collected. 
    All new commercial, industrial and multi-family users shall be required to install at least one properly sized water meter for each unit within the building.

This water meter shall be installed by the applicant before any connection is made to the sewer main. Sec. 8-57. - Same-Service outside village. 
    The charges in section 8-56 shall be increased by one hundred (100) percent for all users beyond the corporate limits of the village. 
(Ord. No. 901, § 3-2-2, 12-19-77) 
Sec. 8-58. - Same-Fees paid to treasurer. 
    All monies paid to the village under the provisions of sections 8-56 and 8-57 shall be deposited with the village treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 901, § 3-2-3, 12-19-77) 
Sec. 8-59. - No connection outside of village limits. 
    After the effective date of Ordinance No. 901, no connection shall be made to either a water main or a sewer main which shall serve property not within the corporate boundaries of the village. 
(Ord. No. 901, §§ 3-2-4, 3-3-6, 12-19-77) 
Secs. 8-60-8-62. - Reserved. 
Sec. 8-63. - Owner responsible for installation of connections; village approval required. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the owner to install properly all piping and necessary appurtenances under this chapter and to furnish all labor or other services associated with such installation of any connection to a water main or sewer main. All connections shall be made in accordance with the specifications of and under the direction and supervision of the authorized agents of the village. No connection shall be used until after all materials and workmanship are approved by the village. 
(Ord. No. 901, §§ 3-2-4, 12-19-77) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations generally, § 2.5-1 et seq. 
Sec. 8-64. - Bond required. 
    In addition to connection charges, the owner or contractor shall, prior to commencement of work on a connection under this chapter, deposit with the village clerk a bond in the amount of three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) in a form satisfactory to the village to insure that work is properly performed and that any disruptions in existing street surfaces or curbs are properly backfilled and repaired. Such bond shall cover water main or sewer main connection(s), or both. 
(Ord. No. 901, § 3-3-5, 12-19-77) 
Cross reference- Bond required for water connections, § 2.5-5(o). 
Sec. 8-65. - Water and sewer expansion and extensions; fees. 
(a)  Fee instituted. A water and sewer expansion and extension connection fee is hereby instituted and shall be based upon prorated share of the cost of the exploration, construction, and extension, which cost was required to provide the sewer and water services being made available to the new or additional users and to reimburse the village for funds so expended. 
(b)  Basis of fee. The water and sewer expansion and extension connection fee shall be based upon all such costs including, but not limited to, engineering fees, supervision, legal fees, financing, land costs, and construction. 
(c)  Population equivalent (P.E.). Upon the completion of any water or sewer trunk line extension, such costs shall be divided by the total population equivalent to be served, here and after referred to as "P.E.," and as defined per the schedule previously adopted in the village's sewer tap on fee Ordinance No. 1171 [1121], section 8-56. 
(d)  Determination of P.E. The water and sewer expansion and extension connection fee P.E. commonly known as the "trunk main service charge," shall be determined by multiplying the number of P.E. times the above described cost per P.E. 
(e)  Additional to tap-on fees. Such charge shall be in addition to any tap-on fees as set forth in section 8-56 of the Code of Ordinances of the village as well as any other usage charges assessed or established elsewhere in the Code of Ordinances. 
(f)  Disposition of revenue received. Revenue from the water and sewer connection tap-on fees and water and sewer expansion and extension connection fees shall be deposited into a fund known as, "the waterworks and sewer expansion and extension connection fund." The funds shall be used to retire debt service and to otherwise pay for the costs as set forth in subsection (b) as incurred in the expansion and extension of the water and sewer system, the monies to the credit of such fund may be invested from time to time by the treasurer of the village as provided by law and all accrued interest on any investment shall be credited to such fund. 
(Ord. No. 1121, § 3-2-1, 4-6-87; Ord. No. 1174, §§ I-VI, 10-3-88; Ord. No. 1266, § 1, 6-19-89) 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 1266, adopted June 19, 1989, renumbered former § 8-56 as § 8-65 and repealed former § 8-65. Such former § 8-65 pertained to the cost of extension of sewer and water mains other than by special assessment and derived from Ord. No. 454 adopted Jan. 7, 1946, and Code 1973, Ch. 6, §§ 3-6-1, 3-6-2. 
Sec. 8-66. - Fee for resumption of water service. 
    There is hereby established a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) whenever the village is requested by any customer, user, owner of premises or occupant thereof to resume the providing of water service to such premises. 
(Ord. No. 1073, § 3-10-1, 11-19-84) 
Sec. 8-67. - Payment of fee in advance. 
    Prior to the resumption of any service as set forth in section 8-66, the twenty-five dollar fee shall be paid in full to the village by the person so requesting the resumption of service. 
(Ord. No. 1073, § 3-10-2, 11-19-84) 
Sec. 8-68. - Minimum charge to continue. 
    The minimum charges for water usage as set out in section 8-51 shall continue to be assessed any customer, user, owner of the premises, or occupant thereof, during any period of discontinuance of service as set forth in this chapter, where such discontinuance was at the request of the customer, user or owner. 
(Ord. No. 1073, § 3-10-3, 11-19-84) 
Sec. 8-69. - When service resumed. 
    The payment of the fee set forth in section 8-66 entitle the customer, owner of the premises or occupant thereof, or the user of such service, to the resumption of such service. 
(Ord. No. 1073, § 3-10-4, 11-19-84) 
Secs. 8-70-8-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - WATER METERS 

Sec. 8-81. - 1977 ordinance. 
    Each person using the water facilities of the village shall in a convenient place attach at his expense a properly operating water meter to the line between the village system and the first water using facility located on private property. Such meters are subject to inspection by employees of the village at all reasonable times. 
(Ord. No. 901, § 3-1-11, 12-19-77) 
Sec. 8-82. - 1971 ordinance. 
(a)  There shall be installed in all water-using facilities constructed on or after the effective date of the ordinance from which this section derives a water meter or water meters as specified from time to time by the village. 
(b)  Such water meters or appurtenances thereto shall be placed where they are easily readable. 
(c)  If it is necessary to replace or repair water meters operating in the village, such water meters shall be replaced by water meters meeting the specification of the village. 
(d)  The corporate authorities of the village shall from time to time set the specifications for such water meters by resolution. 
(e)  Any person not complying with the provisions of this section shall not have water service provided by the village. 
(Ord. No. 739, 9-7-71; Code 1973, Ch. 6, §§ 3-5-1-3-5-5) 
Sec. 8-83. - 1960 ordinance, as amended. 
(a)  Water meters required; fittings generally. All water from the water mains of the Village of Plainfield except water used in a sprinkler system having a detector meter which shall be consumed for any purpose shall be measured through a meter and no premises will be permitted to use water unless a meter of a make approved by the superintendent of the combined water and sewer department shall have first been installed by the consumer. All meters shall be connected with standard brass unions and sealed, and no person shall be permitted to tamper, remove or in any way interfere with the seal as such water meter excepting under authority granted by the superintendent of the combined water and sewer department of the Village of Plainfield. The owner of the building, structure or premises for which such meter is installed or the person in possession, charge or control thereof shall be held responsible for any unauthorized tampering or interference with such water meter, and the water supply to such building, structure or premises shall be cut off and shall not again be permitted to be turned on until such owner or person shall have paid to the village the cost and expense of cutting off and turning on such water supply, provided, that where such person can show that such tampering to said water meter was done in spite of his efforts to prevent same, there shall be no cutting off of the water supply. The village shall have the full right to attach a tag to each water meter bearing the following reading: 
WARNING 
Any person who shall break or cause the seal on this meter to be broken is subject to a fine. 
VILLAGE OF PLAINFIELD 
Any person other than those authorized by the superintendent of the combined water and sewer department who shall tamper with said meter or who shall break or cause to be broken any such seal, shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this Code. 
(b)  Domestic meters. Domestic meters for single-family residences shall be five-eighths by three-fourths inches or such other size that shall be designated by the sewer and water committee or the superintendent of the water and sewer department. 
(c)  Commercial meters. Commercial meters shall be of a size suitable for the line through which water is furnished; provided, however, that the chairman of the water and sewer committee or the superintendent of the water and sewer department may designate a larger meter, if in his opinion it is for the best interest of the village. 
(d)  Industrial meters. Industrial meters shall be of the compound all-bronze type, using only a swing check type valve of two (2) inches to four (4) inches. 
(e)  Sizes. Six-inch sizes shall be determined by the chairman of the water and sewer committee or the superintendent of the water and sewer department as to compound or detector full flow. Meter sizes eight (8) inches, ten (10) inches, and twelve (12) inches should be full flow detector meter for full flow, full accuracy and low pressure loss. 
(f)  Fire lines. Fire lines shall have a detector meter for the purpose of detecting illegal use of water and shall prevent back flow; provided, however, that a detector check may be used in lieu of a detector meter with the written permission of the chairman of the water and sewer committee or the superintendent of the water and sewer department, provided said detector check is Under-writers approved. 
(g)  Repair of meters. Consumers shall, at their own expense, keep the water meters on their respective premises in good repair. Water meters shall be considered out of repair when they are underregistering to an extent of at least five (5) percent; whenever any such meter shall be found to be out of repair, the village shall notify the owner or occupant of the premises on which the meter is located of such fact. The owner or occupant of such premises shall immediately have such meter repaired and put in good condition. If such meter is not repaired within thirty (30) days from the date of such notification, the water shall be shut off from such premises and not turned on until such meter is repaired and the village has been paid for the cost of shutting off and turning on the water. All repairs shall be made by a reputable meter or repair company or by the manufacturer of the meter. Proof that the meter has been repaired and a copy of the test shall be presented to the water and sewer department of the village by the consumer before a meter is declared to be in working order. All parts used in the repair of a water meter must be original factory-made parts. Immediately after the completion of such repairs, such meter shall be sealed by the village water and sewer department. If malfunction of a meter occurs to a meter not then on the market, a meter approved by the water and sewer committee and the superintendent of the water and sewer department shall be immediately installed at the consumer's expense. 
(h)  Inspection and reading of meters to be permitted. Consumers of water shall, at all reasonable hours, permit any representative of the combined water and sewer department of the village to enter their premises for the purpose of reading, inspecting, examining, and testing all water meters and fixtures thereon. 
(Ord. No. 559, 1-5-60; Ord. No. 615, 1964; Ord. No. 664, 9-19-66; Code 1973, Ch. 6, §§ 3-4-1-3-4-3) 
Secs. 8-84-8-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - WATER AND SEWER REGULATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 8-101. - Number of buildings-Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in sections 8-101-8-103, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Sewer service means the sewer line running from the village sewer main in the street to the one (1) building for which it is designed and constructed to serve. 
    Water service means the water line running from the village water main in the street to the one (1) building for which it is designed and constructed to serve. 
(Ord. No. 575, 11-7-60; Code 1973, Ch. 6, § 4-1-1) 
Sec. 8-102. - Same-One building connected or served. 
(a)  No person shall connect more than one (1) building to each sewer service and to each water service. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use a sewer or water service for more than one (1) building. 
(Ord. No. 575, 11-7-60; Code 1973, Ch. 6, §§ 4-1-2, 4-1-3) 
Sec. 8-103. - Same-Exceptions. 
    The provisions of sections 8-101 and 8-102 shall not apply to a garage or a garage and apartment above such garage, provided such garage is used in connection with the one (1) residence served by the sewer service and/or water service. 
(Ord. No. 575, 11-7-60; Code 1973, Ch. 6, § 4-1-4) 
Sec. 8-104. - Subsurface drainage and rainwater-Discharge. 
(a)  No person owning, or in possession of real estate, shall discharge, or cause or permit to be discharged any stormwater, surface water, groundwater, subsurface drainage, uncontaminated cooling water or unpolluted industrial process waters to any sanitary sewer. 
(b)  All downspouts or conductor pipes used to conduct waste rainwater from the roofs of existing and future buildings shall be designed and placed in such manner that no part of the rainwater from such roofs of buildings shall flow directly into any sanitary sewer of the village or into any drain or sewer lines which flow into any sanitary sewer of the village. 
(c)  Footing drains shall be connected to sump pumps and discharge shall be made into storm sewers, sewer lines connected to storm sewers or drainage systems. Sump pumps installed to receive and discharge groundwaters or surface waters shall be connected to storm sewer or into a storm drainage system in a manner approved by the village. Sump pumps installed to receive and discharge building floor drain flow, laundry tubs or other wastewater shall be connected to the sanitary sewer pursuant to the Illinois Plumbing Code and sections 8-141 through 8-149 of the Code of Ordinances of the Village of Plainfield. Each individual sump pump shall be used for one function only, either the discharge of uncontaminated storm-related groundwaters or the discharge of wastewater. 
(Ord. No. 621, 7-6-64; Code 1973, Ch. 6, §§ 4-2-2, 4-2-3; Ord. No. 1312, 1-15-90) 
Sec. 8-105. - Same-Exception. 
    The superintendent of the water and sewer department may authorize the owner of any building serviced by a sewer line at or near the end of any sewer main in the village to discharge such portion of the rainwater from the roof of such building as the superintendent deems necessary to keep such sewer line and sewer main from becoming clogged. 
(Ord. No. 621, 7-6-64; Code 1973, Ch. 6, § 4-2-4) 
Sec. 8-106. - Septic tanks-Permit required. 
    No septic tank shall be installed in the village by any person without first having obtained a permit for the installation of such septic tank from the county health department. 
(Ord. No. 568, 6-6-60; Code 1973, Ch. 6, § 4-5-1) 
Sec. 8-107. - Same-Manner of installation. 
    All septic tanks for which a permit has been obtained in accordance with the provisions of section 8-106 shall be installed in accordance with the instructions and regulations of the county health department. 
(Ord. No. 568, 6-6-60; Code 1973, Ch. 6, § 4-5-2) 
Sec. 8-108. - Same-Inspections; changes; repairs; compliance. 
    All septic tanks in the village shall be inspected from time to time by the county health department as it deems necessary. In case the county health department shall find any septic tank defective or not in proper working order, such health department shall notify the owner and occupant of the premises served by such septic tank, and the village clerk, that such septic tank is defective or not in proper working order, together with its recommendations as to the necessary changes and repairs to be made within a reasonable length of time, not to exceed thirty (30) days from the date of such notice. Upon receipt of such notice, the village clerk shall immediately notify the chairman of the water and sewer committee of the village and the superintendent of the combined water and sewer department of the village. The superintendent of the water and sewer department shall from time to time inspect such septic tank to ascertain whether or not the changes and repairs recommended by the county health department are being made. In case such changes and repairs are not made within the time specified in such notice, the superintendent shall notify the chief of police of the village that such septic tank is being used in violation of the provisions of this article. The chief of police shall immediately cause an arrest ticket to be served on the owner and occupant of such premises. 
(Ord. No. 568, 6-6-60; Code 1973, Ch. 6, § 4-5-3) 
Sec. 8-109. - Protection of potable water. 
    The water distribution system shall be protected against back siphonage and backflow by requiring users of the system to install the following described devices. The installation of such devices shall be a prerequisite to obtaining utility service. 
(1)  All future residential users of the water distribution system are hereby required to install a dual or double-check valve backflow prevention assembly. 
(2)  A reduced pressure backflow prevention assembly shall be installed in any commercial or industrial building constructed after the effective date of this section. 
(3)  That any future commercial or industrial user shall be required to install a reduced pressure backflow prevention assembly. 
(Ord. No. 1321, 3-19-90) 
Sec. 8-110. - Abandonment and sealing of wells; cross-connections prohibited. 
(a)  No water from the village water supply shall be turned on for service into any premises which is tapped on to the village water mains, unless or until any and all existing water wells located on the premises being served shall have been abandoned and properly sealed according to the requirements propounded by the State of Illinois and the Will County Health Department. Such premises shall be subject to visual inspection by the village to assure that the well has been sealed and properly abandoned. 
(b)  Cross-connection between any facility using the village water system and private well systems shall be expressly prohibited. 
(c)  Existing private wells active on sites connected to the village water system shall be abandoned and properly sealed in accordance with this section at the time of transfer of property ownership and/or transfer of water billing accounts. Such premises shall be subject to visual inspection by the village to assure compliance with this section. 
(Ord. No. 1317, §§ 1-3, 2-19-90) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1317, §§ 1-3, adopted February 19, 1990, did not specifically amend the Code; therefore, inclusion as § 8-110 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 8-111-8-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - REPAIR OF BUILDING LATERAL SEWER LINES 

Sec. 8-121. - Sanitary facilities; connected to main sewer line. 
    It shall be unlawful to occupy for either residence or business purpose any building or structure on any lot abutting any street served by the municipal combined storm water and sanitary sewer of the Village of Plainfield unless such premises are equipped with adequate sanitary facilities connected to the main sewer line. 
(Ord. No. 539, 5-19-58; Code 1973, Ch. 6, § 4-4-1) 
Sec. 8-122. - Construction of building lateral sewer line; materials. 
    Every building lateral sewer line extending from the main sewer in the street to the house or building that it serves shall be constructed of either six-inch hard glazed vitreous, hub-jointed sewer tile or six-inch extra heavy cast-iron soil pipe. 
(Ord. No. 539, 5-19-58; Code 1973, Ch. 6, § 4-4-2) 
Sec. 8-123. - General responsibility of property owner or occupant. 
    The village assumes no responsibility for and shall not repair or maintain any building lateral sewer line, commonly known as the sewer service, which extends from the main sewer in the street to the house or building that it serves. The property owner or occupant shall repair and maintain all building lateral sewer lines from such main sewer to the house or building that it serves. 
(Ord. No. 539, 5-19-58; Code 1973, Ch. 6, § 4-4-3) 
Sec. 8-124. - Notice to repair. 
    In case any building lateral sewer line becomes clogged, inoperative or out of repair, the superintendent of the water and sewer department shall notify the owner or occupant of the property served by such lateral, and it shall be the duty of the owner or occupant of such property to repair such building lateral sewer line and put same in operation and in a good state of repair within three (3) days from the date of such notification. 
(Ord. No. 539, 5-19-58; Code 1973, Ch. 6, § 4-4-4) 
Sec. 8-125. - Permit required for repair and maintenance. 
    Before starting any work in the repair and maintenance of any building lateral sewer lines in any street in the village, the property owners shall obtain a written permit from the superintendent of the water and sewer department. 
(Ord. No. 539, 5-19-58; Code 1973, Ch. 6, § 4-4-5) 
Sec. 8-126. - Cutting curb, gutter, pavement, etc. 
    No sidewalk, parkway, curb, gutter or pavement shall be broken, cut or damaged in repairing any building lateral sewer line without the written consent of the superintendent of the water and sewer department. If the superintendent of the water and sewer department finds that in order to repair such building lateral sewer line properly it is necessary or advisable to cut or damage any sidewalk, parkway, curb, gutter or pavement, he shall give the property owner permission to break or cut such sidewalk, parkway, curb, gutter or pavement upon the furnishing to the superintendent of a cash bond, or bond with corporate security, in the penal sum equal to the cost of repairing the damage to such sidewalk, parkway, curb, gutter and pavement as estimated and determined by the superintendent. The superintendent shall promptly deliver all bonds received by him to the village clerk. The village clerk shall receive and hold such bonds pending the repair of such damage. Upon the completion of such work, it shall be inspected by the superintendent. If and when he determines that such repairs have been made in a good and workmanlike manner and all damage to the street, sidewalk, parkway, curb, gutter and pavement has been repaired in a good and workmanlike manner, he shall release the bond in the office of the village clerk, and the village clerk shall promptly refund all cash bonds deposited pursuant to this section. 
(Ord. No. 539, 5-19-58; Code 1973, Ch. 6, § 4-4-6) 
Secs. 8-127-8-140. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - DISCHARGE OF WATERS AND WASTES 

Sec. 8-141. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Ashes means the residuum resulting from the combustion of coal, coke, wood or any other material or substance and shall include soot, cinders, slag and charcoal. 
    BOD (denoting biochemical oxygen demand) means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five (5) days at twenty (20) degrees Celsius, expressed in milligrams per liter. 
    Building drain means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste, and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer. 
    Building sewer means the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal. 
    Combined sewer means a sewer receiving storm or surface water and sewage. 
    Engineer means the duly appointed and qualified engineer of the Village of Plainfield, or his authorized representative. 
    Garbage means solid wastes from the domestic and commercial preparation, cooking, and dispensing of food and beverages, and from the handling, storage and sale of perishable produce. 
    Industrial waste and industrial wastes mean any and all wastes, whether liquid or solid, in solution or in suspension, arising or produced by factories, industries, plants, garages and other business or manufacturing institutions which are injurious and/or detrimental to the sewers, sewerage system or treatment works of the Village of Plainfield or any of the appurtenances thereof or injurious and/or detrimental to the bacterial or chemical action of any of the sewage treatment works; and such industrial wastes shall also include: 
(1)  Waste containing or carrying settleable solids of any character, and any and all floating material of whatever character; 
(2)  Waste containing or carrying either soluble or insoluble solids of organic nature, or containing or carrying either suspended or soluble matter: 
a.  Which is putrescible or capable of putrefaction; or 
b.  Which adversely affects bacterial action; 
(3)  Waste containing or carrying chemicals, acids, alkalies, corrosive, metallic or other compounds, whether soluble or insoluble, organic or inorganic: 
a.  Which are putrescible or capable of putrefaction; 
b.  Which adversely affect bacterial action; or 
c.  Which injure or tend to injure by deposition or by corrosion, the outlets, sewers, sewerage system or works, or any other structures or instrumentalities of the village. 
(4)  Waste carrying, containing or composed wholly or in part of volatile or inflammable materials, fats, oils, grease, tar, kerosene, gasoline or other similar materials or other floating material; 
(5)  Waste containing or carrying any chemicals, acids, alkalies, corrosive, metallic or other compounds, sediment or suspended matter, or mineral matter in solution, or any other material, substance, liquid or thing which is detrimental to or interferes or tends to interfere with the operation of the outlets, sewers, sewerage system or works, or any structures, instrumentalities or processes of the village, by causing or resulting in deposits therein by settlement, precipitation, or otherwise or in any other manner injuring, damaging or interfering with any of the instrumentalities, works or processes of the village. 
    Natural outlet means an outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface or ground water. 
    pH means the logarithm of the reciprocal of the weight of hydrogen ions in grams per liter of solution. 
    ppm means parts per million by weight. 
    Properly shredded garbage means the wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food that have been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch in dimension. 
    Public sewer means a sewer in which all owners of abutting properties have equal rights, and is controlled by public authority. 
    Sanitary sewage means domestic sewage, and sewage discharged from the sanitary conveniences of dwellings and other buildings and places in which sanitary conveniences are used or installed. 
    Sanitary sewer means a sewer which carries sewage and to which storm, surface and ground waters are not intentionally admitted. 
    Sewage means a combination of the water-carried wastes from residences, business buildings, institutions and industrial establishments, together with such ground, surface and storm waters as may be present. 
    Sewage treatment plant means any arrangement of devices and structures for treating sewage. 
    Sewerage works means all facilities for collecting, pumping, treating, and disposing of sewage. 
    Slug means any discharge of water, sewage, or industrial waste which in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds for any period of duration longer than fifteen (15) minutes or more than five (5) times the average twenty-four-hour concentration of flows during normal operation. 
    Solid wastes means trash, garbage, ashes, rags, manure of domestic animals, foodstuffs and the waste thereof other than normally contained in domestic sewage, offal, dead animals or portions thereof, and any and all other solid objects, materials, refuse and debris. 
    Storm sewer means a sewer which carries storm and surface waters and drainage, but excludes sewage and industrial wastes other than unpolluted cooling waters. 
    Superintendent means the duly appointed and qualified superintendent of the water and sewer department of the Village of Plainfield, or his authorized assistant, deputy, agent or representative. 
    Suspended solids means solids that either float on the surface of, or are in suspension in water, sewage, or other liquids and which are removable by laboratory filtering. 
    Trustees means the president and board of trustees of the Village of Plainfield. 
    Uncontaminated industrial waste means wastewater which has not come into contact with any substance used in or incidental to industrial processing operations. 
    User means any person as defined in section 1-2 using the service of the village, or otherwise coming within the jurisdiction of the village. 
    Watercourse means a channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. 
(Ord. No. 662, 8-1-66; Code 1973, Ch. 6, § 4-3-2) 
Sec. 8-142. - Violations. 
(a)  In addition to other penalties, any person violating any of the provisions of this division shall become liable to the village for any expense, loss, or damage occasioned the village by reason of such violation. 
(b)  The attorney for the village may institute and prosecute any and all proceedings, suits and actions necessary to collect any and all fines and penalties imposed with respect to this division, and may institute and prosecute any and all suits at law or in equity as may be appropriate or necessary to present any and all wastes, industrial wastes and the solids or liquids herein or hereby prohibited and/or any and all other necessary suits and proceedings to secure the compliance by any person with the terms and provisions of this division. 
(Ord. No. 662, 8-1-66; Code 1973, Ch. 6, § 4-3-8 (d), (e)) 
Sec. 8-143. - Connection and use fees. 
    As necessary revenue for the construction of facilities for and the operational treatment of sanitary sewage and such other wastes as may be permissible under this division, the trustees shall establish a schedule of fair and equitable connection and service or use fees in accordance with the financial needs of the village; such schedule shall be available in the office of the village clerk and applicable to all commercial, industrial, multiple and single-family dwellings in the village, and such areas as may be annexed thereto. 
(Ord. No. 662, 8-1-66; Code 1973, Ch. 6, § 4-3-3) 
Sec. 8-144. - Connection and usage. 
(a)  No local government, whether village, city or county, shall permit the connection for, or discharge of, other than sanitary sewage into a sewer system which is connected either directly or indirectly to the sewage treatment plant of the village, or which discharges into DuPage River or any other watercourse within the jurisdiction of the village, before permission has been granted in writing for such discharge by the village. 
(b)  When the wastes to be removed from a building consists of both sanitary sewage and industrial wastes, building sewers shall be provided to carry the sanitary sewage and industrial wastes separately to the public sewer when, in the judgment of the superintendent, the industrial wastes may have a deleterious effect upon the sewage works, processes, equipment or receiving waters, or which otherwise may create a hazard to public life or constitute a public nuisance so that such industrial waste may be sample tested and/or measured from time to time. 
(c)  Any person or persons granted permission for connection by the village in writing as described in this division, their heirs, administrator, assigns or successors in interest shall indemnify and hold harmless the village from any and all loss, cost, expense and damage including any and all liability for and on account of any accident or accidents, injury, illness, death or disability caused by or in any manner arising from or growing out of or related to such connection and/or discharge of wastes. 
(d)  No building sewer shall be connected to a public sewer without a written permit issued by the superintendent's office. 
(e)  All building sewers shall be vitrified clay pipe with joints conforming to the American Society of Testing Materials Designation C425-58T, or cast-iron pipe with joints of a type approved by the superintendent. Building sewers shall have a minimum internal diameter of six (6) inches and shall be laid in a fine gravel bedding. The pipe shall be laid on a true grade of not less than one-eighth-inch per foot for six-inch pipe or at a grade to produce a flow velocity of not less than two (2) feet per second for larger pipe. All changes in direction of such sewers shall be made with properly curved pipe or at manholes. The building sewer shall be connected at those locations and in such a manner as directed by the superintendent. The superintendent shall inspect such sewer after the connection has been made and the pipe has been laid. After the inspection has been made the excavation shall be backfilled. 
(f)  Two (2) adjacent dwellings shall each have their separate building sewers. 
(Ord. No. 662, 8-1-66; Code 1973, Ch. 6, § 4-3-4) 
Sec. 8-145. - Use of public sewers; exclusion of solid wastes and industrial wastes. 
(a)  Unpolluted wastes in sanitary sewer. No person shall discharge or allow or cause to be discharged any stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, uncontaminated cooling water, or unpolluted industrial process waters to any sanitary sewer. 
(b)  Discharges into sewers or watercourses. No person shall discharge, or allow or cause to be discharged, either directly or indirectly, any of the following described waters or wastes into any sewer, the DuPage River, or any other watercourse within the jurisdiction of the village: 
(1)  Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil, or other flammable or explosive liquid, solid or gas; 
(2)  Any waters or wastes containing toxic or poisonous solids, liquids or gases in sufficient quantity, either singly or by interaction with other wastes, to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process, constituting a hazard to humans, animals or fish life, or create a public nuisance, or create any hazard in the receiving waters of the sewage treatment plant; 
(3)  Any user, engaged in manufacture or other process, including deactivation processes, in which cyanides or cyanogen compounds are used, shall have every room, where such compounds are used or stored, so constructed that none of such compounds can escape therefrom by means of a building sewer, drain or otherwise directly or indirectly into any sewer, the DuPage River, or any other watercourse within the jurisdiction of the village. Limited amounts, not to exceed two (2) milligrams per liter, may be permitted to be discharged into the sewer system and sewage treatment works, when determined by the superintendent that it would not be detrimental to public health or sewage treatment operation or which would not pollute the DuPage River or any other watercourse within the jurisdiction of the village, and after the state sanitary water board approval shall be instituted by the user and submitted through the village clerk's office, for forwarding by the village; 
(4)  Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than five and five-tenths (5.5) or having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment, and personnel of the sewage works; 
(5)  Solid or viscous substances in quantities, or of such size, capable of causing obstructions to the flow in sewers, or interfere with the proper operation of the sewage works, such as, but not limited to, ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastics, wood, unground garbage, whole blood, paunch manure, hair and fleshings, entrails and paper dishes, cups, milk containers, etc., either whole or ground by garbage grinders. 
(c)  Discharges prohibited when harmful. No person shall discharge or allow or cause to be discharged, either directly or indirectly, to any sewer, the sewage treatment plant, DuPage River or any other watercourse within the jurisdiction of the village, the following described substances, materials, waters or wastes if it appears likely in the opinion of the superintendent that such wastes can harm either the sewers, sewage treatment process, or equipment, have an adverse effect on the receiving stream, or can otherwise endanger life, limb, public property, or constitute a nuisance: 
(1)  Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than one hundred fifty (150) degrees Fahrenheit (sixty-five (65) degrees Celsius); 
(2)  Any waters or wastes containing fats, wax, grease, or oils, whether emulsified or not, in excess of one hundred (100) milligrams per liter or containing substances which may solidify or become viscous at temperatures between thirty-two (32) and one hundred fifty (150) degrees Fahrenheit (zero and sixty-five (65) degrees Celsius); 
(3)  Any garbage that has not been properly shredded. The installation and operation of any garbage grinder other than for residential purposes shall be subject to the review and approval of the superintendent; 
(4)  Any waters or wastes containing acid iron pickling wastes or plating solutions, whether neutralized or not; 
(5)  Any waters or wastes containing iron, chromium, copper, zinc and similar objectionable or toxic substances; or wastes exerting excess chlorine requirement to such degree that any such material received in the composite sewage at the sewage treatment works exceeds the limits established by the superintendent for such materials; 
(6)  Any waters or wastes containing phenols or other taste-or odor-producing substances, in such concentrations exceeding limits which may be established by the superintendent as necessary, after treatment of the composite sewage, to meet the requirements of the state, federal or other public agencies of jurisdiction for such discharge to the receiving waters; 
(7)  Any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such half-life or concentration as may exceed limits established by the superintendent in compliance with applicable state or federal regulations; 
(8)  Any waters or wastes having a pH in excess of five-tenths (0.5); 
(9)  Materials which exert or cause: 
a.  Unusual concentrations of inert suspended solids (such as, but not limited to, fuller's earth, hulls and shells, lime slurries, and lime residues) or of dissolved solids (such as, but not limited to, sodium chloride and sodium sulfate); 
b.  Excessive discoloration (such as, but not limited to, dye wastes and vegetable tanning solutions); 
c.  Unusual BOD, chemical oxygen demand, or chlorine requirements in such quantities as to constitute a significant load on the sewage treatment works; 
d.  Unusual volume of flow or concentration of wastes constituting "slugs" as defined in this division; 
(10)  Waters or wastes containing substances which are not amenable to treatment or reduction by the sewage treatment processes employed, or are amenable to treatment only to such degree that the sewage treatment plant effluent cannot meet the requirements of other agencies having jurisdiction over discharge to the receiving waters. 
(d)  Authority of superintendent. If any waters or wastes are discharged, or are proposed to be discharged to the public sewers, which waters contain the substances or possess the characteristic enumerated in subsection (c) of this section, and which in the judgment of the superintendent may have a deleterious effect upon the sewage works, processes, equipment or receiving waters, or which otherwise create a hazard to life or constitute a public nuisance, the superintendent may: 
(1)  Reject the wastes; 
(2)  Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge to the public sewers; 
(3)  Require control over the quantities and rates of discharge; and/or 
(4)  Require payment to cover the added cost of handling and treating the wastes not covered by existing taxes or sewage charges under the provisions of this division. 
Where pretreatment or equalization of waste flows is required by the village, the design, installation and operation of the plants and equipment therefor shall be subject to the review and approval of the village. 
(e)  Interceptors. Grease, oil, sand and/or grit interceptors shall be provided when, in the opinion of the superintendent, they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts, or any flammable wastes, sand, grit or other harmful ingredients. All interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the superintendent, and shall be located as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. 
(f)  Maintenance of preliminary treatment, flow-equalizing facilities. Where preliminary treatment or flow-equalizing facilities are provided or necessary for any waters or wastes, they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the owner at his expense. 
(g)  Control manhole, meters, etc.-Required. When required by the superintendent, the owner of any property serviced by a building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall install a suitable control manhole together with necessary meters and other appurtenances in the building sewer to facilitate observation, sampling, and measurement of the wastes. Such manhole, when required, shall be accessibly and safely located and shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the superintendent. The manhole shall be installed by the owner at his expense and shall be maintained by him so as to be safe and accessible at all times. 
(h)  Same-Use; when not required. All measurements, tests, and analyses of the characteristics of waters and wastes to which reference is made in this division shall be determined in accordance with the latest edition of Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater, published by the American Public Health Association, and shall be determined upon suitable gambles taken at said control manhole. In the event that no special manhole has been required, the control manhole shall be considered to be the nearest downstream manhole in the public sewer is connected. 
(i)  Special agreements. No statement contained in this section shall be construed as preventing any special agreement or arrangement between the village and any user whereby industrial waste of unusual strength or character may be accepted by the village for treatment, subject to payment therefor by the user. 
(Ord. No. 662, 8-1-66; Code 1973, Ch. 6, § 4-3-5) 
Sec. 8-146. - Cessation of discharge; deposit of prohibited wastes; authority of inspectors. 
(a)  Inspection; report. The superintendent may cause an inspection or inspections to be made from time to time of the premises of any and all factories, industries, garages, dwellings, places of business and places, the sewage and wastes from which are or may be discharged, deposited or find their way, either directly or indirectly into the DuPage River, or any other watercourse within the jurisdiction of the village, or into any sewer within the jurisdiction of the village, for the purpose of ascertaining whether any such factories, industry, garage, dwelling or place of business or the occupant and/or owner thereof is complying with the terms and provisions of this division, and shall report from time to time to the president and board of trustees the result or results of such inspection or inspections. 
(b)  Right of entry. For the purpose of making the inspection or inspections provided for in this section and for the carrying out and enforcing the terms and provisions of this division, the village, by its duly authorized superintendent, engineers, chemists, inspectors, investigators, accountants, attorneys, and agents, or any of them, at any and all reasonable times, shall be admitted and have access to and the right to inspect the plants, places of business, offices, dwellings and premises of any and all persons subject to the terms of this division, and shall also have access to and the right to inspect the outlets, sewers, drains and other instrumentalities of any factory, industry, garage or other place of business or dwelling for the purpose of ascertaining whether any waste, industrial waste or other liquids or solids prohibited by or coming under or subject to the provisions of this division are produced by any such person or persons and for the purpose of determining whether the same are being discharged, deposited or are finding their way either directly or indirectly into the DuPage River or any other watercourse within the jurisdiction of the village or into any sewer or works within the jurisdiction of the village or for any other purpose necessary or proper for the carrying out and enforcing of the terms and provisions of this division. Such representative or representatives of the village shall be permitted to measure the flow to, from or in any and all such outlets, sewers and drains or any part or parts thereof, and to take samples of and from the whole or any part or parts of such flow or discharge at any and all reasonable times, and shall have access to and may examine and inspect any and all records, books, documents and papers covering or relating or pertinent to the determination of the nature, character, extent and volume of any such wastes or industrial wastes and the methods and extent of the treatment, disposal or discharge thereof and shall be permitted to make and take copies and notes thereto and/or with reference thereto. 
(c)  Notice to comply-Generally. If the president and board of trustees shall determine that any factory, industry, garage, place of business or other place of the occupant and/or owner of any building, dwelling or other place is not complying with the terms and provisions of this division, the superintendent or other authorized representative of the village shall serve or cause to be served upon any such person or party not complying with the terms of this division a notice in writing stating and setting forth wherein or in what regard such person is failing to comply with the terms and provisions of this division and further notifying such person that within such reasonable time limit, as may be determined by the president and board of trustees, from the receipt of such notice such person or user shall either cease to discharge such waste, industrial waste or other liquids or solids by this division prohibited either directly or indirectly into the DuPage River or any other watercourse within the jurisdiction of the village or into any sewer, the sewerage system, or sewage treatment plant within the jurisdiction of the village;
